title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. Tha i math agus tha i math dhut!

title: Rosemary Goring  39 s Country Life  the heated question of     heat
story: Here in the heart of the Borders, I look back on that flat with nostalgia. Aside from the occasional draught which we could dodge by retreating to the back room, it was wonderfully toasty. This was in large part thanks to generous neighbours above and below whose central heating kept us permanently cocooned.In the country, as I quickly learned, in winter there are two main subjects of conversation: weather and warmth, but the greater of these is warmth. Hoolet, like many villages around here, has no gas supply, so central heating runs either by electricity or oil. The topic of electricity bills leads to much sucking in of breath, although there was one couple whose house somehow escaped the notice of the electricity board.Only when they sold up and the new owners found they werenrsquot being charged did it become clear why there had always been such a blazing array of Christmas lights in this particular garden. Rumour has it that, years earlier, a woman in this area greased a palm and had her meter erted to a lamp-post. It took a while before the extraordinarily high reading was finally noticed and an investigation began. Soon she was tracked down, along with her cannabis plants.The day is approaching when wersquoll all have to switch to renewables, but in the meantime our radiators drink oil. Every few days I check the gauge on the tank in the garden, half-closing my eyes as I pull out the pin and watch it drop one inch, then two. Since it can take over a week between ordering and getting a refill, you have to estimate how long it will last. If nothing , becoming aware of every drop of oil you use does mean that, while itrsquos the least environmentally friendly of fuels, it is never squandered. One friend is so thrty her grandchildren have renamed her house The Baltic.Long before, and after, they became fashionable, everyone around here wears a gilet. People only come to their doors in a tee-shirttheyrsquove been interrupted in the process of layering. I was watching a western the other night and saw a tobacco-spitting rancher on his porch, rle under his stained armpit. What caught my attention was his long-johns, the sort that reach from ankle to chin to wrist, with buttons down the front. Theyrsquore exactly what I need.Other than the relief of seeing the orange lights of the oil tanker arriving in the pitch black of a winterrsquos morning, there is nothing interesting about oil. Our other source of heat, however, is wood-burning stoves, and on this subject I could win Mastermind. We have two, which possibly saved my husbandrsquos le. When the Beast From the East descended on Hoolet, he was left with a gaping hole in the kitchen wall where the boiler had been taken out moments before the blizzard started. The heating engineers fled to get over Soutra Hill before they were snowed in, and his ordeal began: two log fires and two hot water bottles to get him through five days until the roads reopened. When he went into the kitchen to cook dinner, he had to wear hat and gloves as well as his puffa jacket.There is nothing more comforting in the cold than a roaring fire. In rural parts this is not a lestyle choice but an absolute necessity. Of an evening we get through about five logs, which is enough to keep a large room really cosy. When we started out, we were so ignorant wersquod never even heard the phrase ldquokiln dried and ndash Irsquom going beetroot just thinking about it ndash we bought logs in bags from BQ. Now, having found a good supplier, and with our own woodstore, the first thing we notice as we drive around the area is other peoplersquos woodpiles.Some are works of art, high as a gable end and stacked so expertly theyrsquore as solid as drystane dykes. A few keep them in a ramshackle heap, out in the open, where they soak up the rain. Quite apart from the level of emissions wet wood produces, which is why itrsquos high on the governmentrsquos hit-list, it is far less efficient, generating less warmth and more smoke. Butyoursquore patient, green wood dries out ndash Irsquove heard you should wait two years for anything yoursquove cut down yourself. My father would have scoffed at that, as hersquod bring the car to a sudden halt, nip out and drag a huge storm-tossed branch into the boot ndash ldquotidying up the countryside as he put it. Back home, he stoked the flames so high we had to push the furniture back against the walls and open the living room door.The other day we had a delivery of ash, dumped in front of the house in a crate big enough to hold a wild boar. As the lumberjack was in bed barking like a sea-lion, it fell to me to deal with it. I was well on my way when Lazarus rose from the duvet to check on the proceedings and pointed out that I was laying them sideways rather than end-on. As the sun disappeared and clouds gathered I started again. By this time a neighbour had spotted me, and helped me finish the job.The sense of satisfaction in having it all safely stored, shortly before snowfall, was incalculable. Thatrsquos the thing about wood. The connection between you and the trees yoursquore burning creates a new respect and understanding. For a start, freshly chopped logs give off a delicious scent. And each one is dferent ndash whorled, fissured, misshapen, or neatly wedged like a giant slice of cake. If you chose to count the rings yoursquod see how many years had gone into making a blaze that lasts only a few hours.

title: can-anyone-see-happy-ending-ferry-tales
story: We cannot know what effects will linger from the experience of the past few months and those to come. It could be that the disruption caused by the coronavirus will turn out to be a relative blip and le willto normal, including regular travel abroad. Soon enough, the crowds could be back.It is not guaranteed, though. Travel, even at the best of times, is becoming more trouble than it is worth. Holidays abroad are increasingly spent recovering from the trip there and steeling oneself for the journey back. Hell is the modern airport.Given this, and increased awareness of climate change, more people will want to holiday close to home. Those who come from further afield will expect as eco-friendly a holiday as possible once they get here.Scotland is ideally placed to do well out of these changes. Or it would bewe had a transport system that was not a national embarrassment.The latest snafu is the cancellation of sailings between Brodick and Ardrossan. This is the busiest route in the CalMac network, serving , passengers. It is a flagship service in every sense, essential to Arran residents, businesses, and the wider tourist industry.There cannot be many Scots families who have not spent holidays on Arran. It is a fantastic island, the kind of place most countries would love to have a ferry ride away. The tourist board punts it as ldquoScotland in miniature but a better tag might be ldquoLike Vancouver Island, but closer.: Further ferry delays fearedNot only do Scots make good use of it, we recommend it, and indeed the rest of Scotland, wherever we go in the world. Yoursquoll have a great time, we tell people. To that we should add ldquoas long as you go at the right time.As far as travelling to Arran goes, now is not the best of times. It emerged this week that due to a fault with the mooring equipment ships can no longer berth safely in bad weather. According to CalMac the repairs could take up to six weeks, which runs right into the peak Easter holiday period.Why will it take so long  Because CalMac needs to source spare parts. If the parts were so essential one might imagine they would be held in stock, but that is to assume a level of efficiency that is proving beyond the service operators and their ultimate bosses, the Scottish Government.The latest problems take place against the backdrop of spiralling costs and y delays in the delivery of two new ferries. Vessels that should have cost pound million are now priced at more than double that, and they will not be in operation till  at least.Gavin Fulton, chair of Arran Ferry Action Group, has described the situation as ldquoa shambles. He told The Heraldrsquos reporter Martin Williams that patients on the island were having to spend up to five days on the mainland just to get to a hospital appointment and back.ldquoThings are going from bad to worse for us and there is no contingency plan, he added. ldquoThere is no word of chartering a boat, or to buy one abroad. It is a case of waiting  months for a new ferry and we have to put up with it.Mr Fulton is not alone in his despair. Another essential route, at the Rest and Be Thankful, is prone to closure due to landslips, forcing drivers on a -mile detour. It was announced recently that more millions are to be spent on repairs rather than a reroute of the A. Iain Jurgensen of the Argyll and The Isles Tourism Co-operative said it was ldquostaggering and irresponsible to keep spending public money on patching the problem rather than sorting it out once and for all.: Anger as services haltedIt is not just rural areas that are suffering from the lack of a joined up transport system in Scotland. Rail travel between two of the countryrsquos biggest cities is expensive, unreliable and overcrowded. Bus services across the country y wildly in price and efficiency. In Glasgow the subway does not operate on a Sunday evening. Too often the only way to ensure getting somewhere on time is to go by car, and even then good luck with the potholes.Of course there have been successes, chief among them the Queensferry Crossing. Leaving aside recent closures due to snow and ice the bridge was delivered with only a slight delay, again due to weather, and under budget, something of a miracle for large projects.Yet the Queensferry Crossing aside, Scotlandrsquos transport is too often in reverse or going nowhere fast.Part of the problem is that the subject has become politicised, alongside much  in Scottish le. Take the recent Queensferry Crossing closures. Instead of having a rational discussion about them, the row became another proxy war over Scottish independence. Criticising Scotlandrsquos transport, like questioning educational attainment or NHS waiting times, is seen as ldquotalking Scotland down.It would be funnyit was not so ridiculous. When you travel to another country you donrsquot give two toots of a horn who built what road and when, or who runs the ferry service.: Time to end monopoly of ownershipAll the traveller wants is a reliable service that will take them where they want to go at a reasonable cost both to themselves and the planet. That is what Scots desire as well, and it is not too much to ask.Transport is such an obvious building block for any successful country it should be above political bickering. Even given the problems of geography, it should not be beyond our ability to build a national transport infrastructure that works for all the people most of the time.Since nothing broadens the mind on transport like using the system, herersquos a suggestion. If more of our MPs and MSPs were to venture outside the Central Belt they could see the problems for themselves. Perhaps, once this latest spell of disruption is over, some of them could try commuting from Arran for a spell, or venture beyond the Rest and Be Thankful.Donrsquot forget to send us a postcardand when you arrive.

title: BUDGET SKETCH  Chancellor finds forest of magic money trees  Watch out  Boris
story: Mr Sunak, when seen on his own, looks a regular sized Chancellor. But put him beside someone of average height and build and he appears tiny. Like Stuart Little tiny. You see it when he walks up Downing Street beside another Minister, orhe is being interviewed one to one and the director cuts to a wide shot. On Sky News at the weekend he made the normally petite presenter Sophy Ridge look like the  foot woman, about to attack.Delivering his first Budget yesterday he seemed perfectly at ease. He looked taller, too. Perhaps he had been given a box to stand on, or maybe that is the sort of confidence a bespoke suit gives a chap.Mr Sunak has not been in the job long, having come to the position after the previous incumbent jumped ship in protest at Number rsquos proposed takeover of the Treasury. Dominic Cummings, the PMrsquos chief aide, was all for installing Larry the cat as Chancellor. In the end, Mr Sunak got the job.Among his tasks yesterday was to show that he was a man, not a mouser, and his own man at that. Before he could get to the juicy part of the Budget, handing out the ribbon-wrapped goodies to all his new pals on the Tory backbenches, he addressed the coronavirus crisis.The Commons heard that one fth of the working age population might need to take time off work . That is a lot of people sitting at home watching Phil and Holly on This Morning.Now, you may have been under the impression these last ten years that the UKrsquos finances amounted to whatever spare change could be found down the back of the sofa in  Downing Street. Money was tight, and it was vital to balance the books, so austerity ruled, spending was slashed, and those on benefits had to be squeezed till their pips squeaked. No one wanted to do this, you understand, but as a former PM said, there was no such thing as a magic money tree.Well, it turns out Mr Sunak has discovered a forest of magic money trees. He shook this one, then that one, showering cash left, right and centre. Speaking of left and right, Mr Sunak decided he was going to merge all three positions into one and make Labour redundant. It was the Conservatives, he said, who were ldquothe real workersrsquo party and ldquothe party of public services. Just to further annoy comrade Corbyn he boasted, Blair-like, of delivering ldquoa peoplersquos Budget.The closest the Chancellor came to a half way decent gag was when he abolished VAT on digital books, including ldquoworks of fantasy like John McDonnellrsquos Economics for the Many. Sitting opposite, the man who would have been Chancellor had Labour miraculously won the election, laughed and felt in his pocket ashe was going to reprise his Maorsquos Little Red Book joke of five years ago. A rubbish joke then, age had not improved it.The Chancellorrsquos main rf, one that he ed to again and again, was that the Conservatives were ldquogetting it done. It was the bossrsquos line about Brexit, or was it Cummings who had coined it  Either way, the Chancellor said it so often and with such relish it was ashe had adopted it for his own. Little man, big ambition. Watch out, Boris.

title: brian-beacom-dating-modern-world
story: I looked up and tried to form a bold smile as I lied through my capped teeth. ldquoSo many that my doormat took such a battering Irsquom off to BQ this afternoon to buy a new one.I was entirely unconvincing. The reality consumed both of us. Irsquom single. Uncoupled now for some time, Irsquom almost the age of a Beatles song ndash and I donrsquot feel fine at all.When you reach a certain age you simply canrsquot hang out in bars for fear of being seen as a saddo. The past is another country in which every Friday night was fun night, getting wrecked on white wine spritzers and meeting women themselves a little worse for wear.Some  years on, meeting potential partners is far more problematic. And you canrsquot assume friends will endorse you to single women of their knowing being unmarried at a certain age means women see you as a hopeless case.So what to do  Give up  Get an allotment  Yes, I have to take matters into my own hands. As John Donne almost said, ldquoNo man is an island. And he needs someone to go to the Grosvenor with on a Saturday night with.But itrsquos not easy. As well as the lack of opportunity to meet people, you have to battle against your own torpidity. After a while youget used to your own routine.Then therersquos the fussiness you develop over the years. I once went on a blind date and discovered the meeting to be utterly pointless the moment I noted the femalersquos shoesndash worn for a lunchtime coffee. Therersquos another issue with being single and ageing. The passing years offer experience, a knowing of what you need in a partner, and this knowledge can be inhibiting. Realising you want someone who is intelligent, challenging and fun ndash but also someone who is serious, thoughtful and kind is a heavy boulder to shove. Realising blondes certainly assert themselves on the eye , and that yoursquore a sucker for high cheekbones and a cheeky glint is daunting.Yes, Irsquom asking a lot. And to add to that list I just donrsquot feel comfortable with women bigger than me. So, prospective partners have to be able to limbo under a size  bar.There are notes of optimism, however, to bring to this rather cynical partner quest. Having mutually split with my long-term partner , Irsquove since learned where I truly went wrong:yoursquore going to be with someone for a very long time you should assume they would love to be married. Eventhey never offer the slightest indication of such.Can I commit  Irsquod like to think so. So where to begin with this search to find a we Itrsquos been claimed that more than  per cent of marriages begin online these days, according to figures supplied by the Statistic Brain Research Institute. Thatrsquos good, isnrsquot it Well, Irsquom not so sure. It all seems like HMDI cable connection love. I prefer some form of personal interest to predicate the meeting. I quite liked the high school ldquoMy pal fancies your pal arranged dating, and I thought the premise of the early lonelyhearts agencies to be absolutely sound.My education into this world began in the Kelburne Cinema in  when I watched Carry On Loving. I liked this world. All you had to do was wander into the Wedded Bliss dating agency, the little high street love shop run by Sid Blissand thebig-hearted Sophie Plummett , who would flick through a box of cards and pick out someone whorsquos exactly your type.I recall at  wonderingSophie could pick out someone for me.Fty years on, Irsquom wondering exactly the same thing, except that the personal finger of selection has gone and electronic algorithms, not Sophie, will be used to make the selection. No, Irsquom not keen on this online business at all. Yes, I know seven million in the UK alone are registered. But how can a list of preferences predict chemistry I tell myself to shut up. And havenrsquot the likes of Sharon Stone, Melanie Sykes and Ulrika Jonsson gone online to find a special friend  If nothing , this suggests there are some interesting women out there.Time to start. The first place has to be Tinder, doesnrsquot it  For one thing, the phone download is free. All you have to do is swipe in the direction of the female of your choice, hope that yoursquore her choice and arrange a meet. And before you can say ldquoCongratulations, yoursquore taking her up the aisle.Or are you  For me, the reality of Tinder turns out to be something rather dferent. I wonder, ldquoDo I look as old as some of the women Irsquom swiping away  What a frightening thought.What I also find hard to comprehend is why someone would post pics of themselves with a Bambi nose superimposed, or little devil horns, or cartoon whiskers. Christ, I donrsquot want to go out with a Hanna-Barbera cartoon.What you also learn is that some of the women are eastern European and, rather surprisingly, seem keen to have a much older, rather well-off boyfriend. Perhaps I should be wary.What I do like about Tinder, however, is that people are fairly obvious as to their requirement. I like the women who say, ldquoNo hook-ups, which means they donrsquot want a one-night stand.Yet a Psychology Today profile of Tinder suggests Irsquom more likely to meet a short-termist on Tinder. ldquoSome of those iniduals motivated by such social pressure and instant gratication are also more impulsive, less likely to be faithful and committed, and more interested in having sex for casual reasons, claimed the writer.Irsquove also discovered another possible Tinder problem. One PR company recently created male Tinder profiles, ensuring the name, picture and age remained unchanged, but changed the job title.Claiming to be a builder, they said, nearly doubles your chances of a being Liked. Now, I can hammer home a decent metaphor, mix up a decent simile but I canrsquot treat a damp patchfor the le of me.What I canrsquot nail is a Tinder match. At the last count, Irsquod counted up -odd likes and there are females Irsquove liked the look profile of. But the problem is we donrsquot like each other. It makes me wonder how an app which can have  pages about me on my filendash and million users ndash canrsquot match me up. Surely Sophie Plummett would have pulled someone out of the hat Itrsquos time to look online again. And be optimistic  A survey carried out by dating site Badoo found that people in Glasgow had the best chance in Scotland of landing their Saturday night date. But thatrsquos not love. Thatrsquos a lumber.It seems the problem with internet dating is it represents the paradox of choice. Danish philosopher Soren Kierkegaard once wrote of ldquothe dizziness of freedom. He could have been thinking about the huge volume of internet dating options out there, the anxiety that so much online choice can create. He could have been thinking that, while choice has soared, personal connection has dissolved.Psychologist Michael Rosenfield has underlined this problem. He suggests that finding an online partner is all about learning, narrowing down your criteria,just in case you seek ldquoa same-sex partner, or a partner who is a vegetarian mountain-climbing Catholic.Well, I donrsquot, as it happens. But isnrsquot this all a bit soulless  Does tossing more algorithms at a robot really increase our chances  Or at the end of the day, do we simply connect or not  How can we work out what we want in a partner ndash even when we can never be exactly sure until we meet that person.And letrsquos go back to Glasgow. Online dating company Eharmony says itrsquos ldquothe most single city in Scotland. However, the reasons are not encouraging. ldquo per cent of Glaswegians have given up on finding love completely,  per cent feel overwhelmed by the modern dating landscape and  per cent think theyrsquoll be single forever.Wow. Thatrsquos depressing stuff. The company cites lack of confidence and low self-esteem as playing a major factor. Well, that doesnrsquot apply personally but I have to admit Irsquom edging towards ldquothe  per cent who worry their age is having a negative effect on their search for love.The survey goes on to cite negative past relationships as a factor, and meeting the wrong people on bad dates. ldquoIn fact, a quarter of Glaswegian singles have not had a relationship in over  years.Oh, dear. The allotment beckons. Or having to sign up for a singles holiday in Machu Picchu where Irsquoll meet lots of sturdy women in combat pants and open-toed sandals.I try another internet dating service. Itrsquos called Ourtime and within a couple of hours of filling in the forms I have  likes. I donrsquot knowthatrsquos good or bad. I do know it will cost pound. a month to find out who fancies me. Then therersquos Elite. Which isnrsquot very. Itrsquos claimed to be the dating agency for professionals. I try that one too, but what is a professional  Elite seems to think itrsquos hairdressers or care workers.The website also seems to disregard geography. I declared I wanted to meet someone within a -mile radius and up pops Sandra from Craigavon and Maisie from Nottingham I know. If I were really that keen on finding love Irsquod open my arms to Maisies. I need to widen my outlook. I need to be positive and, like the other singletons, remind myself I live in a city thatrsquos been spiritually blessed by a love saint. St Valentinersquos remains are to be found in St Francisrsquos Church in the Gorbals. And didnrsquot Glasgow proclaim itself to be the City of Love in . That has to help What  can I try  My friend Liam suggests I try Thursday nightsat Waitrose and try to connect over a nice piece of haddock. But then he suggests I follow St Val into church. ldquoGo to mass to meet women, he enthuses. ldquoThere are loads of singles. Andtheyrsquove got kids, all you do is wait until they send the weans up for the Eucharist before making your move.I laugh because Irsquom thinking itrsquos not the craziest idea hersquos ever had. But on the other hand therersquos a real chance I could be hit by a bolt of lightningI recalibrate St Margaretrsquos Chapel as a pick-up place.What of the standard places to meet people these days  Salsa clubs  Yoga  Theyrsquore such a clicheacute but then you have to be in it to win it. Thatrsquos the feeling of Yvonne Carvel, who, along with Diane Goudie, runs the Raeburn Supper Club, which offers a meeting place ndash dinner or events ndash for  to -year-olds.ldquoInternet dating is popular but wersquove been going for  years now and we realised it isnrsquot for everybody. Wersquove learned of lots of less than pleasant experiences.Carvel points out chemistry can only be discovered with a personal meet. ldquoIf you come to a supper club you are met by one of us and itrsquos so much easier to break the ice. And those who register get the chance to meet lots of new friends, with the possibility this may lead to something .She adds, smiling: ldquoAnd it has, on many occasions.What I have learned is that effort is required,chances of meeting someone special are to be realised. Yes, Irsquoll have to advertise myself because standard social structures for meeting people donrsquot really apply as you move into your fties and sixties. Irsquoll have to submit to all-day-long evaluation before complete, often disinterested, sometimes mocking strangers who may find themselves just as dismissive as me because theyrsquore feeling just as anxious.I have to accept that single people need to shop themselves around. In an online blurb can I convince anyone Irsquom sexy, funny, intelligent, honest and decent ndash and the pics are recent.I have to push aside the statistic that claims that . per cent of women agree that money plays a part in how attractive they find a partner.And even though most online relationships fail, one in three begins online. Hang on, herersquos another statistic to end on. Glasgow has been dubbed the British capital of female singletons, with the highest number of single women in the UK, the city having , more single women than men.Surely these are odds I can work with But I canrsquot help thinking itrsquos a Sophie Plummett I need rather than an algorithm.

title: ron-mackenna-not-taste---no-denying-joint-fans
story: Wersquore talking at this table about the enormous To Let sign hanging right outside Bread Meats Bread tonight. And what it means. ldquoNot closing, just moving, says the fresh-faced and chirpy young waiter when asked.When and where, hersquos not sure, maybe six months, probably somewhere bigger. Possibly not the greatest thing for a business to have outside, though, and when I see it tonight en route to find outitrsquos true that Glasgowrsquos Bread Meats Bread now allegedly makes one of the best  burgers in the world, crikey, I almost do a cartoon u-turn.To head instead to one of those new fish taco places popping out everywhere. But itrsquos Wednesday, itrsquos pm and through the enormous square windows I can see a warm glow, a lot of people, a rude healthiness: frankly itrsquos pretty busy.Theyrsquoll sing songs one day about the great burger revolution of, say, eight years ago, of Americarsquos Man v Food, of hipsters and authentic ingredients and the earnest race to make a better burger and of how little Bread Meats Bread here fought off the competition to become not justthe last man standing, but part of a mini Scottish chain with a global reputation. Okay, they probably wonrsquot.But students will surely make documentaries ndash they already have. Although hands up, confession time: I didnrsquot really rate the burgers here when I came back in the day, but whether itrsquos Betamax v VHS, Windows v Apple or simply location, location, location therersquos no denying this place has fans.Mainly but not exclusively males tonight all ages, whisky-loving middle-agers, I see a guy over there chowing down while wearing an actual orange-faced Doxa Submariner watch, a lone Japanese customer at a bench, ayoung couple gazing at each other oblivious to the swooping and swiping at the open grill area above and behind. True story: Irsquoll walk out onto slushy St Vincent Street later just as a clutch of English accents go rushing by and a man will turn and without stopping look up and shout: ldquoHey, great name. But are they great burgers At first I sit at one of those goldfish bowl bench tables thatrsquos at the corner of St Vincent Street and Renfield Street and fight against BTrsquos relentlessly aggressive, greedy, overpriced internet pop-up nonsense from taking over my laptoprsquos wi-fi, but then a back-wall two-seater becomes available and I move to where I can see inside and not just out.The menursquos been through a few hands by the time I get it, but theyrsquove been round the block in here, and itrsquos changed from what I remember too. More buttermilk fried chicken burgers, a plant-based burger from Moving Mountains with, er, genuine bleeding patties, hot dogs too.: Joanna Blythman: It seems to march to its own tune, successfully, for the most part.Their signature burger comes with nduja, pulled pork, BBQ sauce and Sriracha, which gets full marks for covering all the bases. Irsquom no fan of the pile-it-high,bury-the-taste school of burgers so the pound. Cheeseburger is ordered, the small poutineand ndash simply because Irsquom curious ndash a Kimcheese Toastie at pound..The toastiersquos big, toasted properly, sticky, melting and served with a pile of green pickles. The Canadian-style poutine is all bland white curds looking like caullower, a ladle of brown gravy, a few golden chips sticking up like the masts of foundered chips.The burger itself comes in a wrinkled bun, buttered Irsquod say, completely and properly toasted, melting cheese running down what looks like properly charred meat. Theyrsquove got presentation down to almost an art form.Taste  Kimchi toastie  Ooyah: overwhelmed by the taste of that pungent cabbage, and wet at the bottom. Poutine  Harmless and inoffensive.And that burger  The right texture to the bun, clearly carefully prepared, but I find the meat dense, tasting of nothing much and a bit gristly in parts.Bread Meats Bread St Vincent StreetGlasgowTel   Hours am-pm. Seven days.Menu: Itrsquos on an internet list of the worldrsquos top  burgers, plus vegan bleeders, poutines, buttermilk chicken as expected.  Service: No complaints from me, freshly cheery, swt and the food reached the table in a reasonable time.  Atmosphere: Woody, hipstery, open-kitchen vibe, itrsquos part of a mini chain but still pulls off a welcoming feel.  Price: Slap, bang in primo territory in Glasgowrsquos city centre, those rates ainrsquot gonna be cheap but I thought the pricing was reasonable in the circumstances.  Food: Is it fast food with a bit of a hand-made spin  If so itrsquos all of that. Is it one of the worldrsquos best burgers  If so, I had nothing that special to eat and the burger itself wasnrsquot for me.  Total:

title: scientists-close-developing-coronavirus-vaccine
story: Researchers, led by Mucosal Infection and Immunity head Dr Robin Shattock, told thethey have successfully trialled the vaccine in mice and are hopeful it could be ready for human trials by June.Senior researcher Dr Paul McKay, of Imperial College London, told the paper: ldquoIrsquove got results from a month after I injectedand the vaccine works really, really well.:Dental practice closes over suspected coronavirus caseThe team is working with scientists in Paris to determine the vaccinersquos effectiveness in monkeys.Dr McKay said they have applied for further funding from the Medical Research Council to conduct human clinical trials.ldquoIf we get the funding for the human clinical trials, we will put it into people by June, he said.:Coronavirus in Scotland: School shuts amid outbreakldquoIf British scientists here develop a vaccine it would be greatthe Government supported it.Should the human trials be successful, the team is hopeful the vaccine will be available for patients in a year.

title: alex-salmond-tried-kiss-woman-zombie-walk-jury-told
story: The woman said the alleged incident happened at the then First Ministerrsquos official residence shortly before the independence referendum of  and was like ldquoan awful nightmare.She also said the SNP leader asked her to ldquostay over at Bute House.She told the jury of nine women and six men: ldquoI just thought lsquoTherersquos no way in hell Irsquom staying overrsquo.Mr Salmond is accused of sexually assaulting the woman, known for legal reasons as Woman J, by seizing her by the shoulders, trying to kiss her and touching her face and leg.Mr Salmond, , of Strichen in Aberdeenshire, is also accused of  other charges against nine other women, all of which he denies.On the fth day of his trial at the High Court in Edinburgh, Woman J said she had been at Bute House with Mr Salmond after an event, and then gone to the toilet.When she ed, she said Mr Salmond had changed into casual clothes and was lying on the floor of his private living room, and asked her to work beside him.She said: ldquoHe was lying on the ground between the dining table and the back of the sofa.ldquoI froze. She said it made her feelldquoa little panicked.She went on: ldquoHe said lsquoHave you ever seen that zombie movie rsquoldquoHe was still on the floor. As he stood up, he said lsquoget uprsquo.ldquoHe stuck his arms out towards me and did an impression of a zombie. I took a couple of steps away from him.ldquoHe put his arms on my shoulders and leaned in to kiss me on my cheek and then proceeded to move my shoulders to kiss my other cheek and then leaned in to kiss my lips.She said she raised her arms to move his away from her shoulders.Woman J said she was ldquoscared and said she had ldquoabsolutely not consented to being kissed, and took a step back.She said she then went with Mr Salmond to his study, where he put his hand on her leg.She said: ldquoI froze, because of the way I was seated as well I felt trapped.I became very aware there was no-one  in the building except the security guards ndash we were essentially alone.She said the next morning, she woke up ldquofeeling like Irsquod had a nightmare.Woman J added: ldquoI felt with hindsight it was premeditated.Cross-examining, Shelagh McCall, QC, representing Mr Salmond, put it to Woman J that the incident never took place, which she denied.Woman J agreed with Ms McCall that Mr Salmond was a ldquotouchy feely, tactile person who had sometimes kissed members of the public.Ms McCall put it to Woman J thatMr Salmondrsquos behaviour had been ldquoinappropriate, which she agreed.She also agreed she had continuedto work with Mr Salmond after the alleged incident.Earlier, a former civil servant in the Scottish Government told the courtMr Salmond grabbed her bottom ldquoquite forcefully while the pair were being photographed at Stirling Castle in .Woman K said Mr Salmond had been ldquovery insistent she have her picture taken with him after an event, then grabbed her, leaving her ldquomortied.Woman K said: ldquoAs this was happening, the first minister reached down and grabbed my backside. He reached down and grabbed the right-hand side of my backside quite forcefully with his full hand.She described her reaction as ldquoshocked and disbelieving, and said she told her manager.She said: ldquoIt was quite surreal, but at the same time I was having my photo taken and I didnrsquot want to make a scene. I was doing my job.She added: ldquoTime stood still. It felt very deliberate, it was very forceful.ldquoI think my heart stopped, my adrenaline was pumping a bit.She said: ldquoIt felt like I was being demeaned. It was unprofessional but there was nothing I could do about it.The court was shown photographsof the woman with Mr Salmond, in some of which she appeared to have her eyes shut, and to be looking at him in one.Woman K told the court she looked ldquovery embarrassed because of ldquowhat had just happened.She said that when she ed to her office she told her manager. She said: ldquoI told him what had happened,I told him when I was having myphoto taken the first minister grabbed my backside.Cross-examined by GordonJackson, QC, for Mr Salmond, Woman K said she thought the alleged incident ldquowasnrsquot sexual, it was about power.She said: ldquoThat was my interpretation. The first minister grabbed by backside because he could.A third complainer, Woman D, told the court it had been a ldquofairly regular occurrence for Mr Salmond to touch her between  and .The court heard the alleged incidents took place at Bute House, in the Scottish Parliament, in a lt and in a car.The Scottish civil servant said she felt uncomfortable but did not complain as ldquohe was the leader of the country and was worried it might damage her career.Woman D said: ldquoIt was a fairly regular occurrence over two years.ldquoIt made me feel humiliated. I wasnrsquot a valued member of the team.ldquoAt times he would place his handon my back. It made me feel extremely uncomfortable.She agreed it happened more than times. She said: ldquoHe touched my hair, he touched my arm, my neck, my face. It was all cause for concern.Advocate depute Alex Prentice, QC. asked her: ldquoWas this something that you thought you should do something about She replied: ldquoYes. It was pretty well known. He was the leader of the country.ldquoI really liked my job, and I felt like I complained or made a formal complaint, it would be my word against his and it would damage my career.She said it would have been ldquoalmost unimaginable to bat his hand away.She said Mr Salmond had also reached out to touch her face in a lt, and a male civil servant had ldquobatted his hand away and asked Mr Salmond what he was doing.Mr Jackson later askedshe once showed Mr Salmond a holiday snap of herself in a ldquosomewhat skimpy bikini.She said she had only done so because Mr Salmond had asked to see her holiday photos. Mr Jackson said:ldquoI take it you donrsquot just take bikini photos  Why show him that one Woman D replied: ldquoI donrsquot know.The male civil servant later told the court about the alleged lt incident.He said: ldquoI reached out and battedhis hand away. It was an instinctive reaction, it happened very quickly.ldquoThe former first minister reached out, and [Woman D] shrank back, andI brushed his hand away. I think I said lsquostop that, behave yourselfrsquo.Mr Jackson asked him: ldquoDid you feel the former first minister was in danger of behaving inappropriately The witness said: ldquoYes.The trial, before judge Lady Dorrian, continues.

title: scottish-independence-coronavirus-blow-indyref2-changes-scottish-political-landscape
story: Every development at Holyrood, Westminster, Brussels or wherever must observe this natural law.Everything either illustrates the logic and appeal of independence or reveals the folly and misery of the Union.Every statement and deed by Boris Johnson puts more numbers in the Yes tally, according to the SNP. As does everything , come to think of it.In SNP press release after press release, in speech after SNP speech, we are told there is only one direction of travel ndash onwards and upwards. :New poll published on Scottish independenceCome good times or bad, boom times or busts, rain or shine, nothing can ever be admitted to arrest the cause of independence, far less set it back. There is only forward motion.Which brings us to the coronavirus.Talented though the media mavens of SNP HQ may be, it is hard to put a positive spin on a traumatic pandemic.Most inconveniently, there are some things which are not in the business of boosting the Yes vote after all.But what dference will it make We are still only in the foothills of the outbreak, and the global economy has already been knocked sideways and le for millions disrupted.Far, far worse lies ahead.So it might seem indelicate to bring politics into the equation. But in truth politics never leaves the equation. It is a constant choice about how we live.:New indyref poll - Fewer than three out of  want another vote before In our small corner of the world, the virusrsquos impact on independence is already under discussion. One fellow scribbler this week suggested it would do the cause ldquono favours.SNP MPs duly pushed back on the idea that a pan-UK response with a whf of the Blitz spirit to it would undermine the case for going it alone.Some, no doubt, will also be pondering how the virus might reconfigure the electorate given the most vulnerable voters are also those most opposed to independence.But I believe most of our politicians, both at Holyrood and Westminster, will simply have the same instinctive concerns about friends, family and society as the rest of us, and do their best to help the country get to the other side of a grim summer.That said, I fear the virus will be more than a match for Nicola Sturgeon, Mr Johnson and their respective public services.People, in their distress, will look for someone to blame. But as the diseasersquos rapid spread has blind-sided the planet, I donrsquot think either leader will be seen as especially culpable. However, I do think the independence debate will change in both the short and medium term.For one thing, Ms Sturgeon can now drop the dim pretence about a second referendum this year.Boris Johnsonrsquos refusal after the general election and the lack of relevant powers at Holyrood always meant Indyref was a non-starter before the  Holyrood election, and possibly for some time after that.Yet to maintain a symbolic flicker of hope, and to avoid getting blamed by her own side for dropping the ball, the FM has kept diminishing herself by insisting it is still a live possibility.That can now end. The outbreak means Indyref this year is logistically and politically impossible.Besides ruling out a campaign involving hundreds of thousands of voter contacts, the virus has become every governmentrsquos Priority One.The public will not stand for money and manpower being erted into naked politicking while it rages.And despite the protestations of SNP MPs against columnists, the independence cause will suffer.Not necessarily because it will look like a bad fit for times of crisis. But because it will look like a decidedly second-order issue.Ms Sturgeon hasnrsquot been able to deliver Indyref so far, but she has been shrewdly fostering a sense of inevitability about it happening.She steadily built momentum, and was set to capitalise on it in .That is about to change.The Yes movement is entering a stall. No marches, no campaigning, no way to spin independence as an answer to the great issue of the day.That loss of hard-won momentum and a slide down a shell-shocked nationrsquos list of priorities will change the Scottish political landscape.However, that does not mean the SNP Government will be greatly disadvantaged at next yearrsquos election.The Scottish Tories, after all, had been planning to hammer the SNP on their -year record in office.But the virus throws a spanner in the stats they intended to deploy.The usual ammunition ndash fresh AE waiting times, treatment guarantees and exam results ndash wonrsquot be there.Instead, there will be a gigantic aberration, a freak lurch in the data arising from a natural disaster.Voters may remember the one-off failures like faulty hospitals and half-built ferries, but the Tory line that the SNPrsquos record has been on a steady downward track will struggle.Nor will Jackson Carlaw be able to credibly claim he could have handled the pandemic better. It will dwarf everyone.The question for a re-elected SNP would then become when is the right time to restart its old conversation When is the right time to say that independence is again the priority It may be a long time indeed.

title: scots-ferries-fiasco-lifeline-island-replacement-seven-years-late
story: Plans to replace the ageing ferry serving Islay have not yet even gone out to tender - four years after the Scottish Governments transport agency said it would actually have been built.Islay islanders believe the fiasco delays to building two ferries at newly nationalised Ferguson Marine have had a knock on effect on the progress of what transport minister Humza Yousaf said two years ago would help support its growing economy.The dual fuel replacement Arran ferry Glen Sannox and her sister - Vessel  - were due to enter service in mid- but the calamitous contract has doubled in price - and is now estimated at poundm - while work on the vessels will not be finished until at least  - four years late.: First Ministers "great regret" over state of Scotlands busiest leline ferryIt was five years ago, that Ferguson Marine in Port Glasgow was handed the pound million contract to build the two ferries.Last year distillers on Islay said they were facing major problems in transporting whisky over to the Scottish mainland because of a capacity crisis on the ferry links.CalMac, the taxpayer-owned ferry operator, has traditionally served Islay with two vessels, the MV Finlaggan and the -year-old MV Hebridean Isles, one of the oldest in the -vessel Scottish fleet.According to an eight-year-old Transport Scotland plan, the estimated timing for replacing MV Hebridean was up to , and sources have said the two vessels do not offer the capacity Islay needs to service its whisky and tourism sectors.The new ferry to complement MV Finlaggen is to have a clear focus on freight and sufficient passenger accommodation to meet anticipated demand.But according to the latest Transport Scotland estimates, a shipbuilding contract for the new Islay vessel is not expected to be awarded until the Autumn of this year, with the first phase of the tender not being initiated till the summer of this year.:First Minister intervention call over parlous state of Scotlands busiest ferryIn , Transport Scotlands Vessel Replacement and Deployment Plan had stressed that the MV Hebridean Isles should be the next ferry to be replaced.And two years ago Mr Yousaf in a statement titled "Islay ferry pledge" said that officials were investigating potential designs.Islay Community Councils ferry committee has raised its concerns about the delays with ministers complete with a dossier of issues that have beset the route from the Argyll and Bute mainland hamlet of Kennacraig to the island.It said thatthere had not been the delays in building Glen Sannox and her sister Vessel , the replacement ferry might even have been place in  - six years later than planned - but it now fears it will not be delivered until the middle of .Ferry committee chairman Jim Porteous said: "A key reason for the delay has been the Ferguson Marine debacle and the delay in completion of the the ships at their yard."The side launch of the CalMac ferry Hebridean Isles at Selby in the s.The committee said that in September  alone, a peak time for the Islay route,  sailings were cancelled due to a redeployment of one of the Islay vessels to support the Arran service. Ten further sailings were cancelled in March, last year for similar reasons.In December , there were eight cancelled sailings after the Islay ferry was redeployed to cover Oban, due to a ferry breakdown.The committee said: "Without action, further ongoing disruption can be expected for the Islay service, including inability to travel and extra costs for residents, lack of ferry capacity for trades people and visitors and major income losses for the tourism industry.": Scottish ferries fiasco - Questions over shipyard deals as illegal state aid cases emergeOn March , two meetings will be held in Islay to discuss the requirements and specications of the new ferry. They will be hosted by Caledonian Maritime Assets Limited , the taxpayer-funded company which owns ferries and other infrastructure used by publicly-owned operator CalMac, which will also be represented with Transport Scotland officials.Jim Anderson, director of vessels at CMAL, said: ldquoWe are working closely with all parties to develop the specication for a vessel that meets requirements and supports the islandrsquos economic activities."In , there were , crossings by commercial vehicles between Islay and Kennacraig on the mainland in ,  or .% more than the year before. That number is forecast to rise on the back of new distillery openings.Last year, it was forecast whisky production on the island will increase by  per cent in the next three years.With increased numbers visiting Islay because of the growing popularity of whisky tourism, it was estimated that an additional , extra car spaces will be needed by .Transport Scotland said: ldquoMinisters have committed to a new ferry for the Islay service. Transport Scotland and the Steering Group are currently taking forward design and specication for the new vessel which is lsquobased onrsquo the lead vessel on the route, the MV Finlaggan, as a starting point in terms of vessel dimensions."

title: fidelma-cook-say-wise-lockdown-easy
story: Because I am marked as high risk in the coronavirus epidemic on two fronts ndash age and COPD ndash I may as well cross my arms over my chest and lie down in my coffin the second its presence is detected.I already have to avoid crowds, air pollution, scented candles, woodsmoke etc andyou have a cold then, sorry, you canrsquot come in. Thatrsquos how fragile my lungs are.In France , suffer from COPD and many are not old nor have they been smokers. But like me their systems are compromised. For you a cold is a cold for us itrsquos often a trip to AE.So imagine how we feel when some commentators blithely suggest that, as it only really harms the old and the infirm, best let it do so and have a cull.Forgive meI have no wish to be culled, for my le may not be as rich or as vibrant as it once was, but I am not ready to shuffle off just yet.Itrsquos extremely irritating to see young people heading out on the town because they know theyrsquolljust receive a mild form ofCovid-. Indeed, you probably will but the person yoursquove just passed it on to by your callous disregard could die.It is chilling to know that, as there are simply not enough ventilators to go around, someone like me will not be on the list for intubating ndash only those who have a better chance of recovery.I understand that hard decisions are taken daily in hospitals and not as lightly as it may seem. In Italy nurses on the frontline are often in tears as they turn away from the elderly and fragile and any hope of keeping them alive.As of today, in France, we have  dead and almost  infected. But experts fear the figures are way under-reported because of a shortage of testing kits.By the time you read this many more will have died as the virus follows the projected pattern.At the moment, in the grisly league table of cases, we come second,vying with Spain for that dubious honour.Gatherings of more than  have been banned, sporting fixtures postponed and there is a surfeit of advice from government departments.President Emmanuel Macron is doing a television address to the nation. The subject is naturally coronavirus and presumably further plans for containment.Many, as the true scale of it has been accepted, are hoping for an Italian-style lockdown.Many, like me, are alreadyself-isolating. A recent survey claims that a quarter of all voters say they will not be going to vote in the first round of our municipal elections tomorrow.As in Italy, the bulk of the cases are in northern France but, like spilled ink, it is spreading further south daily. The nearest death to me is in Montauban,  minutes away, but it is a town regularly used by all of us here.Plus, further south in Nice, Cannes and all the villages in between, locals think nothing of crossing to Italy for shopping, the markets or even lunch.Struck low the past few weeks by an excruciating bout of sciatica, I have been dependent on my sainted neighbour Miriam and the daily nursesrsquo injections of Ibuprofen to keep me up to speed as to whatrsquos happening locally.People are no longer kissing, elbows are extended in lieu of handshakes, the odd mask has been seen and the only panic buying has been of hand sanitiser and antiseptic wipes.The nurses smile comfortingly and say: ldquoNot in our cornerhellip yet.They say Irsquom wise to be in lockdown. But then itrsquos easy for me here.I am responsible for only myself and Ceacutesar. I donrsquot go out to work and no employer can dock my wages for staying home.In the silence of the country I am well used to days and weeks of solitude so I have no fear of being alone without human contact.Between Miriam and my femme de meacutenage, my shopping is done, my needs met.Oh, I know how lucky I am to have a neighbour like her.With them as my bedrock, all I need is heat, light, books and my Mac and I can watch the world in its madness and destruction.For those not used to such isolation it will be hard. It has taken a good few years to become this sanguine and I can only be so as long as my health holds up.I have stopped railing against my misfortunes and found a sort of acceptance. Well, itrsquos hard to do otherwise given the circumstances.And many, many, more are in far worse situations than me.So clicheacuted to say it but, God, le turns on a sixpence.I feel almost nostalgic now for the passion andfire of the Brexit days. Simpler times. Safertimes.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: IN these tough times, itrsquos good to see the SNP trying to lt peoplersquos spirits by hawking them overpriced tat. The party yesterday started shting a ldquolimited edition independence paperweight for just pound.. The blurb is positively North Korean. It was ldquocreated by none other than the First Minister herself. Itrsquos true! it gushes. Aided by an actual glass maker, ldquowith admiral dexterity the First Minister shaped the glass until she was entirely happy with the finished product... What a result! There are  of the black and yellow lumps to cheer a grateful nation. Like independence, theyrsquore even being delivered after ldquoa slight delay.No prizesAS is traditional in Pyongyang, the glorious leaderrsquos family also gets a mention in the sales pitch. Ms Sturgeon may have chosen the ldquotwo very familiar colours, but it was her husband, the SNPrsquos chief executive, who christened it so brilliantly. ldquoThe chosen name of this stunning paperweight was agreed by Peter Murrell. His choice was, wait for it!... lsquoIndependencersquo. No prizes for guessing that! And no prizes for the copywriter either. Still, what an inspiring backstory to contemplate as you stare into its gloomy depths while self-isolating.Western MilesSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford famously described himself as a ldquohumble crofter in the House of Commons. However the Edinburgh financier turned Skye MP isnrsquot exactly known for the simple le. One car dealership recently published a picture of the rustic poseur on its forecourt next to a pound,-plus motor: ldquoWarmest wishes to our loyal customer Ian, collecting his wersquos new Range Rover Velar from our Inverness showroom, it said. To which Tory MSP Murdo Fraser replied: ldquoThatrsquoll be handy on the humble croft, Ianhellip.The picture, like Mr Blackfordrsquos humility, has now disappeared.Ferry rudeALSO being catty this week was Green MSP John Finnie, who slipped a zinger into the Holyrood inquiry into the CalMac ferries fiasco as it quizzed officials from state-owned ferry firm CMAL. The MSPs had earlier heard from Monaco-based billionaire Jim McColl, whose business had owned the shipyard that tried to build the boats before going bust. Or as Mr Finnie put it slyly, ldquoWe heard from Mr McColl, who I understand is non-resident in Scotland and himself isnt a taxpayer, but he was very concerned about Scottish taxpayers money."Cheese operatorMEANWHILE, Nat finance minister Ben Macphersonseems to be stockpiling cheese for the coronavirus outbreak. The Leith MSP this week took to social media to boast about his latest musical purchase. ldquoAbsolutely superb! he declared of the  CD box set compilation lsquoSmooth Rockrsquo. Amazon reviews of the -track easy listening ordeal are tellingly bland. From the thoroughly sensible ldquovery reasonable price to the splendidly circular ldquoIf youre a fan of this genre of music then this is a great CD for you. Or as Ben might say, Smoooooth.Very revealingDISCLOSURE Scotland bosses got a well-deserved thrashing from Holyroodrsquos Public Audit Committee on Thursday over a computer fiasco that went poundm over budget. MSPs were gobsmacked the quango couldnrsquot even publish its minutes online, far less deliver a major IT project. Also squirming was Government justice mandarin Paul Johnson. Askedmore IT disasters were coming down the track, he offered a classic civil service platitude. ldquoIrsquom quite sure there will be continued learning, he said. In other words, loads of lsquoem.

title: eigg-basing-annual-film-festival-abundance-wildlife-birds
story: Now Eigg is celebrating its winged wildle by staging the islandrsquos first film festival with a bird-themed programme.The festival programme of  feature films and documentaries will run over four days from Friday, March .A late-night screening of Alfred Hitchcockrsquos The Birds and Nick Parkrsquos animated comedy Chicken Run, as well as festival opener, award-winningThe Messenger ndash which chronicles the mass depletion of songbirds across continents ndash will be shown between the Community Hall and CineMorrsquos custom-built cinema yurt.Nature expert Dr Kenny Taylor will give a talk on how seabirdsrsquo global travels bring them back home to Eigg, while wildle cameraman Jim Manthorpe and sound recordist Pete Smith will talk about, and show films, they have made for BBC, National Geographic,Channel  and others.A birdwatching sail and walks series, sound recording workshop, a concert by singer-songwriter Jenny Sturgeon and a special Bird Bubble Bath DJ set from Eiggrsquos very own The Pictish Trail with CineMorrsquos bird projections, closethe Eigg Film Festival.Norah Barnes, the islandrsquos Scottish Wildle Trustrsquos summer warden, has lived on the .-mile by -mile island for  years and is leading the birdwatching walks around the island, armed with binoculars and telescopes.She said: ldquoWe just really want to help people find out more about the birds.If you can see them up close it really makes a dference ndash itrsquos like a whole other world just on your doorstep.ldquoThe wildle around us is incredibly rich. Eigg has a large iety becausewe have lots of dferent habitats.ldquoWersquove got all the shore birds and waders but then wersquove got moorland birds nesting and birds that use thelochs for nesting. Bigger birds usethe clfs and we also have forestryand woodland.In her role as summer warden, from April to August, Ms Barnes surveys the ieties of dferent wildle on the island, including the birds, seals, butterflies and moths, as well as conservation work to preserve the environment.The data collected allows the wardens to monitor the wildle and is passed on to other nature agencies.For Mr Taylor, former Highlands and Islands regional manager for the Scottish Wildle Trust, Eigg and its populations of people and birds are close to his heart.He said: ldquoEigg is in a very fortunate position that, in quite a small package itrsquos got a whole range of dferent kinds of places that wildle as a whole can use, and birds in particular.ldquoItrsquos got a very good mix of dferent birds, whether itrsquos hen harriers in the low ground, ers on the lochs, wee birds in the woodlands, and a whole range of other birds around the coast.As part of the Small Isles archipelago, Eigg hosts birds that travel the globe including the Manx shearwater seabird.Once seen in huge numbers on the islandrsquos clfs, the population has greatly diminished over the years due to the historic practice of coastal communities eating chicks and indigenous vermin.Mr Taylor said: ldquoThere were miles of shearwater colonies, which was incredible, but now they are down to maybe -plus pairs.ldquoJust over the sound is Rum, one of the biggest colonies in the world.ldquoEigg is part of a jigsaw in the Small Isles for seabirds as part of the whole community of birds.Festival co-ordinator Lucy Conway said: ldquoAdding a film festival to Eiggrsquosyear-round calendar of events is very exciting.ldquoEigg has many iconic bird species and is a must-visit place for birdwatchers. Islanders love birds and understand visiting birdwatchersrsquo fascination. Wersquore really looking forward to enjoying four days sharing that passion throughmoving image, guided walks, talks, workshops and more.Robert Livingston, director of Regional Screen Scotland said: ldquoRegional Screen Scotland has long-standing links with Eigg, through the visits of our Screen Machine mobile cinema.ldquoSo we are delighted we have beenable to support the very first Eigg Film Festival through our Local Film Festival Challenge Fund, made possible by funding from Creative Scotland.For more information or to buy tickets see: www.eiggfilmfestival

title: louisiana-postpones-primary-states-scramble-adjust-coronavirus
story: Louisiana last night announced it will delay its primary vote next month because of the outbreak, with a new date set for April .But Arizona, Florida, Illinois and Ohio insisted their votes would go ahead as planned.Ohio Secretary of State Frank LaRose joined his counterparts yesterday in a joint statement affirming that their statesrsquo primary elections would take place on Tuesday.:Scientists close to developing coronavirus vaccineldquoAmericans have participated in elections during challenging times in the past, and based on the best information we have from public health officials, we are confident that voters in our states can safely and securely cast their ballots in this election, and that otherwise healthy poll workers can and should carry out their patriotic duties on Tuesday, a statement said.Elections officials around Ohio reported that they are losing poll workers scheduled to work Election Day because of fear about the spread of the coronavirus.Mr LaRose earlier this week ordered local elections officials to move voting locations at about  senior living facilities to new polling places to insulate residents of those facilities from the spread of the virus.Ohio has five confirmed cases of Covid-, and about  others were under investigation. Governor Mike DeWine signed an order on Thursday banning most gatherings of + people.:Coronavirus in Scotland: Cancer treatments are hit as crisis deepensHowever the order does not apply to voters casting their ballots in the election.Polling places are dferent from other large gatherings, the secretaries wrote, because they draw people from smaller communities together for a short period of time.Concerts, sporting events and other large gatherings, though, draw from a broader area and for extended time.Voting machine manufacturers also have provided information about how to sanitise machines, and local boards of elections have received information from health officials about hand-washing, they wrote.Mr LaRosersquos office told county boards this week that they will be reimbursed for buying sanitisers, disinfectants, disinfecting or antibacterial wipes, disposable gloves, rubbing alcohol or isopropyl alcohol, and other sanitising materials.ldquoAs each of our four states prepare for voters to head to the polls on a Tuesday, March , , we are working closely with our state health officials to ensure that our poll workers and voters can be confident that voting is safe, the secretaries wrote in their statement.Elections officials in Ohio have been encouraging voters to cast early ballots or to vote absenteethey do not want to go to the polls.But the pandemic threatens the US election. Democratic rivals Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders both cancelled rallies in Cleveland, Ohio, on Tuesday, citing recommendations from public health officials to avoid assembling large indoor crowds.A televised debate tomorrow between the men in Arizona, will take place without a studio audience or media ldquospin room.But the Trump campaign announced a ldquoCatholics for Trump coalition launch in Wisconsin, on Thursday next week, where the president is expected to address thousands of supporters asit were business as usual.It came as, last night, President Trump declared a national emergency to handle the growing outbreak in the US.The declaration ndash ldquotwo very big words, according to Mr Trump ndash allows the federal government to tap up to bnin emergency relief.The move loosens medical insurance regulations, and could speed up the creation of new hospitals and the search for new treatments.There are , confirmed cases of Covid- in the US, and  deaths. Several US states have taken measures to stem the inflation rate, banning large gatherings, sporting events and closing schools.Mr Trumprsquos administration has come under recent scrutiny over its failure to provide Americans with widespread coronavirus testing.

title: three-people-test-positive-coronavirus-glasgow-university-campus-stops-face-to-face-teaching
story: The university announced on Saturday morning that three iniduals are currently self-isolating after testing positive for the virus.It comes just hours after university bosses confirmed they would cease face-to-face teaching from Monday , and all exams scheduled to take place in April and May would be taken remotely.It is not yet knownthose affected are students or staff at the university.They have now advised that some conferences may be cancelled in wake of the positive cases.Live updates as flights turn in mid-air over fears of the coronavirusA statement on their Twitter feed reads: "We want to advise you that  iniduals have tested positive for COVID-  all  are self-isolating."Guidance from health officials is that cases like these are to be expected given the outbreak."Confirmation of positive results is entirely to be expected as the pandemic evolves. Were working closely with Health Protection Scotland  will remain open ndash though, face-to-face teaching will cease from Mon  March."As a precautionary measure, we are in touch with Glasgow University Student Representatives Council,the student unions and others across our campuses to discuss postponing events such as conferences. Some of these have already been cancelled.:Jet flights to Spain from Glasgow, Birmingham, Leeds, Manchester and East Midlands cancelled and turn back in mid-air amid coronavirus fears"We would like to reassure you that we are taking all precautions  in contact with Health Protection Scotland. Well continue to monitor the situation closely  provide regular updates as soon as we can. title: coronavirus-unclear-covid-19-infection-passed-newborn
story: The infant and its mother both tested positive at a north London hospital and staff who had contact with the pair have been advised to self-isolate.However, scientists say that they remain unclear about how the transmission of the illness occurred and have urged calm.:Coronavirus: US adds UK and Ireland to European travel banRichard Tedder, Visiting Professor in Medical Virology, Imperial College London, said: ldquoThe description of the apparent detection of Covid- infection in a newly born child of a mother with Covid- infection herself raises concerns about the potential ways in which this transmission may have occurred.ldquoIt is important to say at this point in time that the detection of Covid- nucleic acid on the sample from the child does not necessarily mean that the child was infected. It could well have come from the mother at the time of delivery, further follow-up of the infant will clary whether or not the infant is infected."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Which surfaces are spreading Covid- ","description": "Which surfaces are spreading Covid- ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media zTzISD poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests zTzISD.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": ldquoPrevious data from colleagues in China, published in the journal The Lancet, albeit on a small number of mother and infant pairs, did not show infection in any of the infants at the time of birth. Neither did sampling of breast milk immediately after birth containdetectable virus. Thus, the UK observation of a possible neonatal transmission is unexpected and needs further confirmation.ldquoThe question of risk to a newly born child being nursed by a mother who is known to be infected is a matter that will need careful consideration.:Jet flights to Spain from Glasgow, Birmingham, Leeds, Manchester and East Midlands cancelled and turn back in mid air amid coronavirus fears"The absence of detectable virus in breast milk would appear to reduce the risk of breastfeeding however the close, intimate and entirely understandable contact between a mother and her baby will raise questions about how best to care for them. Compounding this too is the lack of knowledge of the clinical outcome of neonatal infection, should this actually occur.

story: Two new cases of coronavirus have been confirmed in Scotland, bringing the total to three.One is in Grampian and the other in Ayrshire.Both patients were said to be clinically well and receiving care.One recently travelled to northern Italy and the other has had contact with a known positive case – this contact was not with the first positive case confirmed in Scotland in Tayside.Clinicians have begun contact tracing, the process of gathering details of the places they have visited and the people they have been in contact with.Health Secretary Jeane Freeman said: “Our first thoughts must be with the patients diagnosed with coronavirus, I wish them a full and speedy recovery.“We expect the number of cases to rise and Scotland is well-prepared for a signicant outbreak of coronavirus. “There is currently no treatment or vaccine so early detection measures will continue to be vital in helping to prevent the spread of the virus.“People have a vital role to play in helping us contain any outbreak by following the latest health and travel advice, and following basic hygiene precautions, such as washing hands frequently, not touching their face and covering their nose and mouth with a tissue when coughing or sneezing.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.kincardineshireobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt""  Aberdeenshire licensing boards could merge viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "KINC | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "KINC | Article Teaser"

title: top tesla prize for petrolhead
story: A self-confessed petrolhead from Insch is making the switch to a top of the range electric car after winning a Tesla Model  Performance worth #, thanks to dream car competition, BOTB.Contest winner Mike Lynch, who also bagged £, in cash, admitted he played for the Tesla in a bid to be more “environmentally conscious” after switching to an electric car in the last few months.He was surprised with his win over the phone by BOTB presenter Christian Williams on Monday, February  before being flown down to Windsor, Surrey, where he was put up in a -star hotel.Mike was shown his prize Tesla the following day.Up until recently Mike had been driving a Range Rover V, however in a bid to be more green recently switched to the BMW is electric car because Tesla was too far out of his price range.Commenting on the new motor Mike said: This is an incredible car.“Its performance matches that of most sports cars and it’s stacked with gadgets - and I’m a real gadget man.”Mike works for an automation engineer for an oil company, developing solutions to help the company reduce its carbon footprint. “I work in reducing how much fuel we are using, so having won an electric car is quite fitting in that respect,” he said. “The way I see it is we’ll all be driving around in electric cars soon enough, so it’s good to get one and get used to it - but this will be in style.”Having first owned an off road motorbike at the age of seven, Mike has been hooked on all things motoring and motorsport ever since, going to watch the British Grand Prix at Silverstone on numerous occasions with his dad Allan. “The first thing I’ll do when I get the Tesla is drive it down to my parents in Edinburgh,” he added. “There’s no way I’d have been able to take the is as the charge wouldn’t last the journey, but the new Tesla will.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: ex salmond aide seeks nomination
story: A former special adviser to Alex Salmond has announced she is seeking the SNP nomination for the Aberdeenshire East constituency.Jenner Dempsie, , currently works as a media columnist and public relations consultant. The former First Minister will stand down at Holyrood next year after winning the Gordon seat in May’s Westminster election.Ms Dempsie helped run several election campaigns, was public relations manager for the pro-independence Yes campaign in the run-up to last year’s referendum, and is a former associate director at global communications agency Weber Shandwick.The political hopeful, who was a special adviser to Mr Salmond when he was First Minister, says her former boss would be a tough act to followshe becomes a candidate.She said: “Alex Salmond will be greatly missed in the Scottish Parliament. He has served his constituents with passion and diligence both as their MSP and as First Minister, which he is of course continuing for them at Westminster.“If selected as candidate, I would want to run a positive campaign for progressive politics to re-elect an SNP government to continue the job of working hard for the people of Scotland and, importantly, for the people of the North-east.“My priority would be to roll up my sleeves for everyone across Aberdeenshire East campaigning for the best educational and work opportunities by protecting traditional and promoting new industries, ensuring the local economy is connected with strong transport links, tackling inequality, protecting our NHS and vital public services, as well as the vulnerable who are being hit hard by the Tories’ continued austerity.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Richard Thomson and his campaign team celebrate the SNP victory."
