Members of the public ar e invited to join in a spring clean in Park village in the Faughan Valley this Saturday, March . Woodland Trust will be sprucing up the allotments and the community tree nursery on the day. Those taking part will get the chance to plant seeds, tidy up and take home their own tree sapling from the nursery. Volunteers will also get the chance to bring home their own eco-wildflower pot.Bronagh Gallagher, project officer for Woodland Trust at Faughan Valley, said the event was ideal for everyone, including families. She added: “What better way to teach your children to be aware of their environment and get green fingers!“This will be a fun event and anyone can join in and get hands-on. We will be doing all sorts of activities on the day including planting seeds and transplanting seedlings – we are even giving away free tree saplings from the nursery.”To join in the community event, email bronaghgallagher@woodlandtrust.org.uk to book your place. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A Derry brewery has launched a new gin in honour of a famous aviator with close links to the city.The amazing exploits of American aviation pioneer Amelia Earhart are being commemorated in the first ever Derry gin.The new Earhart Gin is named after the world-famous aviatrix Amelia Earhart, who became the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic.Taking off in Newfoundland, she originally planned to complete her epic -hour flight in Paris but suffered technical problems, and landed in the Cornshell fields in Culmore on the outskirts of Derry in May .Walled City Brewery owner James Huey said he was delighted to launch the new drink.“We’re incredible excited to be launching Derry’s first ever gin.“There has been a huge increase in gin sales globally over the last  years, and we are keen to put Derry back on the map as a producer of world-renowned spirits. “Our creative director Brigid Johnson has designed an iconic brand identity which will stir up our passion for Amelia and her astonishing achievements,” added Mr Huey. googletag.cmd.push RecipeJosh Kyle was also involved in the creation of the new drink.“We’ve spent nearly a year developing the recipe with a secret blend of classic gin botanicals such as juniper, coriander, pink peppercorns and angelica root. “But we wanted to truly reflect Derry by hand-foraging some unique wild botanicals from the meadow she landed in, and added hawthorn berry, elderberry and a gorgeous native flower called purple saxrage.“The aroma and flavour from these are truly amazing. We’ve also used our mixology experience in the restaurant to develop some gorgeous new cocktails using the Earhart Gin. ‘New Foundlove’ is a stunning local apple-based gin cocktail, whilst ‘Little Red Bus’ is named after Amelia’s own nickname for her bright red plane and is a fabulous twist on the classic Bloody Mary.” googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. How are you  You okay  What about ya  How’s it going  So many times I’ve heard people say this to each other. Yes, I’m talking about youBUT did you actually stop to HEAR the reply or is it just a ‘saying’ you churn out, a habit you say when, in actual fact, most of the time you say it, they say it and neither of you answer. Was nursery good today , What did you do today  are questions I hear most days from parents collecting children from nursery and school. BUT most of the time I actually think WHY ASK as two minutes laterthe parent is not actually talking or listening to the child.So what’s the point of asking  If you really are interested then take the time to listen. Don’t bother asking how are you your really don’t want to know. Yes, this does sound a bit harsh. I know I sound tough. BUT the simple truth is we do need to listen to each other more, be more aware of how our friends, family and, of course, our toddlers and children feel. How we feel is important, it links directly to our self esteem, our self confidence, our willingness to try new things, our ability to cope with problems, our ability to manage upsetting and worrying situations, our ability to form and maintain friendships whether we be two years old or . It involves understanding and being aware of our feelings and how to manage feelings of sadness, loneliness, anger and hurt. It is only by talking about how we feel that we learn to manage these feelings, find a way to overcome them so they don’t drown us, make us feel alone and unable to cope. We hear and see lots of messages in the media about mental health, about the importance of talking and listening to each other, but it is a two way street. If you are feeling down, your toddlers tantrums are getting too much, you are worried sick about the mounting bills, your boss is being unfair and expecting too much or you simply feel lonely, you must speak up and say. How can your family and friends helpthey don’t know -you paint on a smile then close the door and the tears come  In school this week, I had to teach pupils, aged six and seven, about being aware of how they feel and can make others feel. These discussions you can have at home, even with younger children, simple discussions about playing together, not leaving friends out, sharing, kind hands, what to dosomeone has no one to play with, what they could do or saysomeone in their class looks sad. What should they dothey hear someone being mean, someone being picked on, orsomeone makes them feel sad, breaks their toy, paints over their picture etc. I finished the lesson with a simple, ‘what nice thing did you do today.’ You can try this as a family at home. I had so many lovely answers, I played with Sophie, I made Jack laugh, I gave Matthew a turn of the ball, I wonder what nice things you and your children will talk about at tea time today It is important to remember your toddler and younger pre-school child when thinking about feelings too, talking about how you feel when they eat up all their tea, do a nice picture, play nicely with their baby sister etc. But to also talk about when they made you feel sad, when they didn’t tidy up, or cross when they shouted at you. This encourages an awareness of feelings and also enables them to learn about and name dferent emotions. Simple songs such as ‘If You Are Happy And You Know It’ can also have lines such as If You Are Sad Cross etc. Looking in the mirror together and making emotional faces can be fun too. Or make happy plates - happy faces on one side and cross or sad on the other and talk about what makes them feel this way. And, of course, books, talk about the characters how did Baby Bear feel when Goldilocks broke his chair and ate his porridge, how did Spot feel on his first day at nursery So that’s you, your family and friends sorted, but what about the person you don’t know  I know we can’t be responsible for everyone butwe share the message that feelings matter, support mental health awareness, then we can make a dference to each other and through a smile to that other person. The person who felt weighed down and your smile bought them a little bit of happiness, a little lt in a dark day, a thought that people do care, For, in the words of Mother Teresa…Every time you smile at someone, it is an action of love, a gt to that person, a beautul thing.So IF you’ve time to listen then ask how are you  If you are in a rush, say, sorry, I do hope you are good, or sorry, you know where I amyou need me, or big smiles to you or let’s catch up soon - do call me BUT don’t be in a rush every time and DO call! As for your toddlers and children and coming out of school, talk, listen, talk, listen TALK, LISTEN!Remember talk to your doctor, health visitor or your child’s teacheryou are worried about yourself, your child or someone  and, of course, visit Sure Start which offers lots of supportive services for families with young children. Plus many of the wonderful community services in Derry may be able to recommend a group or support service for you - just ask! You may also consider, Mental Health Service nidirect website. Some  years after captaining Maghera to MacRory glory against St Colmans, Sean MartyLockhart is on the other side of the line. Michael McMullan sat down with him to chat MacRory and also dug up a few insights from others on Lockharts days in the blue, white and black. Our sport coverage is brought to you in association with TJ Hamilton Cookstown Leader and perfectionist were two of the words the  edition of Magheras school magazine, The Patrician, used to describe MacRory winning captain Sean Martin Lockhart.In school tradition at the time, every senior  member would have a short synopsis penned about them. Lockhart was described as one of the most complete colleges players for a long time.“He was as solid as a rock, as youd imagine and he was always on the dangerman,” adds Padraig McKaigue who, with no previous goalkeeping experience, played behind him for both Derry minors and Maghera.McKaigue also points to a roasting Lockhart dished out to current Cavan minor manager Mickey Graham in an Ulster minor semi-final.Damian McErlain, who played on the  team with Lockhart, rated Magheras full-back line that year – John Heaney, Niall Farren and Micheaacutel Kelly – as the best he has played with or managed.“Nobody will ever appreciate how good they were,” he states.And then there was Lockhart. McErlain remembers the No Fear t-shirt Sean Marty would often wear and the jovial Niall Farren giving him plenty of stick for wearing it.“You can practice, practice, practice – Ill still beat you,” read the slogan on the back. It was made for him reckons McErlain, who played at centre-forward. His battles with Lockhart at least once a week at training were savage.“Some days you just never got a ball,” McErlain remembers. “Then, youd have a good day and hit - or something. You knew about it the next day – he took to you like a days work.”Now,  years after captaining Maghera to a -point final win over St Colmans, Lockhart leads Maghera into another final against their Newry rivals.Thenearly didnt happen. Lockhart had initially planned to leave school after fth year to become an electrician. There were also murmurs of a route into accountancy.“I would never have saw myself as a teacher or a manager. Back then, I had a job in an accounts office,” Lockhart recalls, but now there are no regrets.“Its a flash,” said Lockhart, of his memories. “I am talking to you about this years final...that was our year and I cant believe it is  years.”Back in the day, the careers room was the hub for pre-game meetings. Adrian McGuckin would address the  with a detailed and pristinely bound portfolio, specially commissioned for every game. It had everything from bus times to warm-up details. From a team list to a synopsis of the other teams strengths and weaknesses. There was a plan for playing with an extra man or having a man sent off. Every base was covered.Now, that corner on the second floor of the three-storey building houses the school staffroom. The faces have changed, but constant murmur of football chat competes with the aroma of hot tea.Lockharts MacRory career spanned three and a bit seasons. In , as a fourth year, he was added to the  towards the end of the campaign. The following year, he was corner-back. They needed two games to get over a St Patricks Armagh attack that had the bustling Des Mackin on the edge of the square.“Dessies gonna get you,” came the chants in the direction of Seanie McGuckin, who would win the battle. The final was a dferent story against St Colmans. Mackins county minor team-mate Diarmuid Marsden missed a penalty, but the Violet Hill men still took the cup, on their way to a Hogan title.In , Seanie McGuckin was now the fulcrum of the attack, leaving Lockhart to wear the number three jersey. Maghera went one better with St Patricks Armagh in the Athletics Grounds. Lockhart gave away height and weight to full-forward Conor McGurgan, but not much  in assured performance.Another masterclass, as McKaigue put it, came against Pat Spillanes nephewin a landslide win over St Brendans Killarney to set up a date with St Jarlaths Tuam and a chastening - to - defeat.It was a team that included Michael Donnellan, Padraig Joyce and Tommy Joyce, John Divilly, Declan and Tomas Meehan.“We had no specic plan to go for goals, but we were encouraged to go for themthey were on,” reveals former Donegal player John Haran, who was on that Jarlaths .“If you ever watch that game on video, Maghera actually had a lot of possession and missed a lot of chances. History is cruel, as it looked like an easy win.”Full-forward for Jarlaths was underage superstar John Concannon. He scored - that day, but failed to reach the same inter-county heights as the rest of the crop. Harans St Eunans team-mate Kevin Winston lashed in the first goal, before the Concannon show kicked in. It was a humbling hour for Lockhart.”All through that year, there was a chant  youll never beat Sean Lockhart but after  minutes hehad skinned me, scored - and the chant just stopped.” googletag.cmd.push  MacRory and Hogan champions. It was his last chance at a Hogan Cup medal. The following year, , he was one of six players, including starters David ONeill, Mark Diamond and Fintan Martin, who were overage for the All-Ireland series. Panellists Sean McPeake and Dominic Lynn, who wouldve been in contention, were also ineligible.The MacRory would be his last hurrah. In the quarter-final against St Macartans Monaghan, with Lockhart now as captain, goals from David ONeill and Mickey Gribbin put them on their way.Six days ahead of the semi-final, Maghera – with eight starters missing – defeated St Jarlaths Tuam, who had  of the Hogan winning team on view, in a low-scoring challenge game in Aghadrumsee. It was the perfect ending to the preparations.“We had a strong upper six and a strong lower sixth group. We were coming off the back of winning the Rannafast and there was great character in our team with a never say die attitude,” Lockhart feels. “We played Abbey . They had John McEntee, Tony McEntee, Enda McNulty and Aidan ORourke at a snow-swept Armagh.”Leading - to - at the break, Maghera had to face the elements in the second half but a Mark Diamond thunderbolt ot the net, into the driving snow, quashed any Abbey hopes. Now preparing for the final as a manager, Lockhart can now fully appreciate the support structures from his playing days.“Back then, as a player, you are in a wee bubble and Adrian protected us and he kept our feet firmly on the ground“Now as a manager, you have to organise food, travel, promotion and the media, so you see the whole package. But one thing you do see, you see the impact on the school. As a player, you thought it was about us in the team. It didnt go totally to plan for Lockhart in .“I remember breaking my finger the year before the final. I was playing pool with a few of my mates and we were just messing about.”It didnt matter, the final was a walk in the park. Colmans got the first point of the game, the only time Maghera were behind all year. That was as good as it got for the Newry side. They failed to score for over three quarters of the game and Lockhart – who also kicked a point - was left to lt the cup.It wasnt long until he received the call from Derry senior manager Mickey Moran. Within three years of leaving school, he would pick up an All-Ireland U medal and was full-back on the last team to win the Ulster SFC, in .He never gave Tony Boyle a kick in the Ulster final and combined with a performance on Padraig Joyce later in the year, he picked up an all-star.It was a baptism of fire in the early seasons as an inter-county defender. He vividly remembers a league clash with Clare and a tough afternoon marking Gerry McInerney. Lockhart has never forgotten the name.“I was wing-back and he scored - off me and skinned me. The older boys, like Henry Downey and Kieran McKeever, came over and said Sean Marty, you have made the county, your learning starts now.“I went back into full back and you had to educate yourself. You had collective training and there was the inidual work yourself. I had plenty of battles with boys after it.”Over the next week, Magheras defenders dont need to look any further for advice on how to curb the St Colmans attack.As our conversation finishes, Liam Kielt appears on the scene. After a brief, general, natter on football, his former Corn na nOacuteg manager enquiries about the Newry challenge. Lockhart recites a litany of names and dangers.“They have a good forward line,” was the sweeping statement centred on next Tuesdays taskThe preparations had long since begun. The  school magazine wasnt far off the mark. Leader. Perfectionist. Boys and girls U- GAA teams in Derry gearing up for this year’s John West Feacuteile can win €, of kit by creating videos of their clubs’ Feacuteile memories.Natural protein experts John West, who sponsor the Feacuteile na nOacuteg and Feacuteile na nGael U- football, hurling and camogie tournaments are preparing for the competition finals with a €, kit giveaway to teams.The  John West Feacuteile na nGael hurling and camogie finals take place in Dublin, Kildare and Meath on the weekend of June -.This year, the John West Feacuteile na nOacuteg football finals will be held across Donegal, Derry and Tyrone on the weekend of June -.Throughout its sponsorship of the Feacuteile, John West has focused on encouraging children to participate in Gaelic Games while emphasising the importance natural protein plays in fuelling a young athlete.Four GAA Clubs now have the chance to win €, each towards their Feacuteile  kit.Entries are now open and to be in with a chance of winning, all teams have to do is send a short video through the Teamer app featuring their club’s best Feacuteile memories.Ideas can include profiling a Feacuteile hero, photographs set to music of a magical Feacuteile moments, Feacuteile journeys, the role of your coach, training highlights, parental support and host family memories.“Before we know it the John West Feacuteile finals will be upon us,” said Lucy Gratton of John West“We know getting to the finals requires fundraising to support the journey. That’s why we are giving four clubs the chance to win €, each towards their Feacuteile  kit.“A core aim of Feacuteile is to promote the philosophy that every player should participate at a level fitting with their age, skills and strengths as well as allowing clubs to play against and foster links with teams in other counties and provinces.“Creating and sharing special memories is also a very important part of Feacuteile and we would like clubs to use the Teamer app to share a video which highlights this.“There are four prizes of €, on offer, one each for a boys’ gaelic football club, girls’ gaelic football club, hurling club and camogie club.” googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Research has revealed that one in  motorists find parking to be a stressful experience. While parking availability can determine what parking style a motorist must use the research also highlighted preferences with  per cent of respondents selecting parallel parking over  per cent who chose perpendicular parking. Most annoying parking habitsParking scenarios can be tricky to navigate, and other drivers’ behaviour can have a huge impact on it, increasing the stress levels of motorists. When asked what motorists found to be the most annoying parking habits of other drivers the following where revealed as the top five:- Hogging two parking spaces - Parking in a disabled space when they had no disabled sign and weren’t a disabled driver - Parking too close to your car - Blocking you in so you can’t get out of your parking space - Blocking an entrance so you can’t get into your home or place of work  Commenting on the research, CEO of easytrip Ireland, Colin Delaney said: “While advanced technology has made parking hassle free for many there will be times that parking becomes stressful.“This could be down to parking preference spaces not being available or other drivers’ behaviour. “We would encourage drivers to take their time when parking and seek out a parking space they are comfortable with parking in. “It’s important to be considerate of other motorists needs and this includes parking between the white lines, not on them. Not parking in a space that is not dedicated for their use, whether that be a disabled, family or electric vehicle space, and not parking on double yellow lines. “Ultimately it’s about being considerate of others and making driving and parking less stressful for everyone.” googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. The North West Cricket Union has announced that it is to receive funding of pound, from Derry  Strabane District Council to help support the high-profile International T games between Ireland and New Zealand at Bready scheduled for this summer. Kane Williamsons side will play a three-match series against the hosts with the games taking place on ,  and  June.Bringing the World Cup finalists to the North West is a massive coup for the local Union however with the game set to attract global attention and television viewers in the millions worldwide, the staging costs will be high.Union Chairman Brian Dougherty and General Manager Peter McCartney have been hard at work in terms of attracting the necessary funding over the past number of months and were delighted to get the green light from Council last week.Confirming the details of the support, Mr Dougherty said that DSDC had agreed to help with the cost of ground equipment, legacy grassroots programmes and marketing  media promotion. The confirmation of Councils financial commitment to this major sporting event represents a signicant landmark in relations between our Union and DSDC. We are grateful not only for their monetary contribution but also for how they have committed to ensuring the series helps promote the region on the world stage he began.We are confident their support will also help lever additional finances going forward. This of course is also testament to the work of the Union, the hosts Bready CC and also Eglinton CC who will facilitate New Zealand training sessions during their stay here. We must also recognise the ongoing support of Cricket Ireland for cricket in the region and their backing for staging such high profile games in Bready. googletag.cmd.push OpportunityMayor, Michaela Boyle echoed those sentiments and suggested that this was an opportunity to show the sporting world what the North West has to offer.“The Cricket World Cup finalists coming to Bready for a competitive senior international is exciting news not just for cricket fans but for the wider sports fraternity in the North West.“I am delighted that Council have been able to support this high level fixture through the National Event Fund and I would like to congratulate Bready Cricket Club and the North West Cricket Union for their tireless work to secure these games.“This is one of the biggest sports fixtures to ever take place in our Council area. The games are an opportunity to showcase our region as a host for world class sports events both to the many spectators who will arrive in the city and to the viewers of Sky Sports.“We look forward to working with Cricket Ireland to host the players and supporters of New Zealand and cricket fans from all over Ireland, we can promise you an unforgettable experience in our City and District.” googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. title: Ballynahinch woman Jean enjoys 100th birthday joy
story: A BALLYNAHINCH woman celebrated her centenary with family and friends at Spa Nursing Home last Thursday. With her fresh complexion, sparkling eyes and ready smile, few would believe that Mrs Jean Kelly is  years old.Secretly enjoying the fuss, Jean appeared happy to be sipping tea from a bone china teacup and saucer at her birthday party, which was attended by family, friends and staff members.While Jean grew up in the Roaring Twenties, it wasnrsquot all flappers and jazz bands around Lisowen mdash the townland outside Saintfield which was her home.Born Jean Stewart, she lived with her grandparents and attended Doranrsquos Rock National School, a small two-room country school between Saintfield and Crossgar.When she left school she went to work at the Montalto Estate in Ballynahinch, which was owned by the aristocratic Clanwilliam family.Youngest son Malcolm takes up her story.He said: ldquoIt wasnrsquot long after she began working there when one fine evening she was pushing her bike along the Creevyargon Road toward home, exhausted after a dayrsquos work when she met a young man walking toward her in the other direction.Malcolm explained the young man was so taken by Jean that he offered to push the bike for her.ldquoThe young man was my father, Hugh, and within three years they were married, said Malcolm.Hughrsquos family were dairy farmers from the Creevyargon Road. When the couple got married Jean gave up her job at Montalto, as was customary in those days.Jean and Hugh were to be blessed with six children, three of whom mdash Malcolm and his elder sisters, Irene and Anne mdash are still alive. Two of the children died in infancy and another daughter, Margaret, passed away a few years ago.Jean has been a widow for over  years but her fabulous tapestries and hours spent volunteering at local charity shops are testimony to someone who enjoys being busy. One of her finely embroidered pieces hangs proudly in the nursesrsquo station at Spa Nursing Home.Some years ago, Jean visited northern France and sewed the magnicent medieval monastery of Mont-St-Michel, set in the bay of St Malo where Normandy and Brittany merge.She is also a keen local historian and is particularly knowledgable about Betsy Gray and the Battle of Ballynahinch in .Jean also enjoys John Wayne films, including Rio Bravo and She Wore a Yellow Ribbon, and the musical Seven Brides for Seven Brothers which starred Howard Keel. She is also a great fan of country music legend Jim Reeves.Jean has been a resident at Spa Nursing Home for almost four years and son Malcolm says she could not he happier. ldquoThe staff are very good to her, he remarked..prettyPhoto

title: Call for investment in Ardglass harbour
story: THE importance of the Ardglass fishing industry to the district and wider South Down economy was highlighted at a meeting at Stormont last week.Fisheries minister Edwin Poots met with South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillor Dermot Curran to discuss planned improvement work at the port, including deepening the harbour to facilitate larger herring and mackerel vessels.The local politicians highlighted the need for additional investment in the harbour and its infrastructure and called for the port to receive its fair share of funding to enhance the fleet.Mr McGrath described Ardglass as a ldquostrategically important harbour for the Co Down fleet, highlighting its crucial role in driving the South Down economy and its location as a central hub for processing fish.The MLA said further investment was ldquocritical to allow Ardglass harbour to expand with appropriate slipways provided to allow larger vessels to dock safely.ldquoSuch work should be undertaken in concert with efforts to expand Kilkeel harbour and ensure that our local fishing fleet is enhanced ahead of Brexit, Mr McGrath continued.ldquoSouth Down has a proud association with the fishing industry. It is beyond time that we invested in this important part of our economy, creating new jobs and bringing new opportunities to local people.Cllr Curran mdash who invited Mr Poots to visit Ardglass to see the port at first hand mdash said such a visit would provide an opportunity for the fisheries minister to see that the development of the harbour is ldquoessential for the day-to-day lives of people in the village and the economic prosperity of South Down.He said that the local port is home to a large fishing fleet which lands some of the largest quantities of prawns in Ireland. In addition, Cllr Curran explained that Ardglass is the only all-weather harbour between Howth and Bangor.ldquoThe main economic activity in Ardglass is the fishing industry and although it is reasonable buoyant at present, harbour improvement is needed to sustain it., Cllr Curran continued.ldquoThis improvement is required to facilitate the large fish and prawn boats as they have encountered issues with access.Cllr Curran explained that due to their size, a number of vessels have scraped along the sea bed at low tides entering the harbour, causing damage to their hulls which can result in vessels being out of commission for repairs. leading to a loss of earnings.ldquoSome of the larger boats now bypass Ardglass and go where, mainly to Belfast, he continued. ldquoThis results in a loss of landings and additional transport costs to the local fish factories.Cllr Curran added: ldquoIf Ardglass harbour is not deepened, it could potentially lead to an economic collapse for the fishing industry in Ardglass and that is something no one wants to see happening.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is supporting plans to regenerate Ardglass harbour to help secure the future of the villagersquos fishing industry and has provided financial support to a harbour development group which has drawn up a series of proposals.The money was designed to help the group complete a business case aimed at paving the way for a number of projects including deepening the harbour to accommodate larger herring and mackerel vessels and to upgrade berthing facilities for local trawlers.The Ardglass group is also keen to relocate trawlers to the an area known locally as the Saw Pit at the harbour which it wants to deepen in order that vessels are able to put to sea when they want and not have to wait on the right tidal conditions.The provision of a dedicated repair facility for vessels is also a key aim for the new group as currently trawler skippers have to take their boats to Kilkeel or Portavogie which reduces the time they can spend at sea earning a living.Another key plank of the grouprsquos vision for the future is converting property at the harbour to provide a new hub offering essential office and training space. It is also hoped to provide a storage and work area and space for the community to use..prettyPhoto

title: Coronavirus: St Patrick’s parade off
story: NEXT Tuesdayrsquos St Patrickrsquos Day parade in Downpatrick has been cancelled over the coronavirus threat.Itrsquos only the second time the cross-community carnival has been halted since it was started in the s mdash it was called off in  due to the foot and mouth health crisis.Newry, Mourne and Down Council yesterday confirmed that parades would not go ahead in Downpatrick or Newry after party leaders on the council decided to pull the plug.The council has also cancelled open-air activities in St Patrickrsquos Square, but other events in Down County Museum and Down Arts Centre are going ahead.Chief executive Marie Ward spoke yesterday morning with the DUPrsquos Billy Walker, Sinn Feinrsquos Willie Clarke, UUPrsquos David Taylor and the SDLPrsquos Pete Byrne for their views after Belfast City Council voted to cancel its parade on Monday night.Dublin also cancelled its St Patrickrsquos Day parade, the largest event held on the island.A council spokesperson said the decision was made ldquoin consultation with party leaders and is in line with the recent cancellations of St Patrickrsquos Day parades where.The spokesperson added: ldquoThe council appreciates the negative impact this decision may have on local businesses at this time, however this decision has been taken as a precaution given our membersrsquo and the publicrsquos concern around the coronavirus response.The townrsquos religious ceremonies are to go ahead as planned.A service of Holy Communion in St Patrickrsquos Church of Ireland Church at Saul will be held at .am.The traditional mass in Irish and the distribution of shamrock will take place in St Patrickrsquos Church at am and the cross-community service will take place in Down Cathedral at .am.The Dean of Down, the Very Rev Henry Hull, said while he understood peoplersquos concerns, he pointed out that Patrickrsquos Day was also a religious festival and that services would be taking place as normal.ldquoPart of our theme this year is prayer for the country which is very apt at this time, he added.Mournes councillor Willie Clarke was the first politician to call for the event to be cancelled.The Sinn Feacutein man said it was ldquoessential to have an all Ireland response to this epidemic, which is spreading rapidly across Europe.He said: ldquoI believe there is an obligation on myself and all councillors to protect the health and well-being of citizens, given the spread of coronavirus and growing concern amongst the public.He said that the decision was not taken lightly but it was ldquothe responsible thing to do.Cllr Clarke added: ldquoI would like to see an event held at a later dateit is possible, to reschedule these celebrations, as sections of the business community will undoubtedly see a reduction in business, and the British government need to provide resources to mitigate these losses.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker said he felt that there would have been an increased risk to Downpatrickthe parade had have gone ahead as it could have attracted people who normally attended the Belfast event.ldquoWe may have had the situation that we would have increased crowds with increased risk, said Cllr Walker.ldquoI think itrsquos the right decision to take. I completely sympathise with all the council officials and employees who have planned the event, and of course all the community groups who love to take part and who have put in months of hard work with float and costume preparation.ldquoBut at the end of the day we have to think of health and public safety.Council vice-chairman Terry Andrews, of the SDLP, said he fully supported the decision but added ldquothat it was most unfortunate it had to be taken.ldquoCouncillors have done the right thing and itrsquos better to be cautious to minimise any potential risks, he said.South Down MP Chris Hazzard praised the council for its ldquoproactive and responsible leadership to protect our citizens in cancelling the parade.He added: ldquoThere will of course be huge public disappointment and hard-felt financial repercussions for our local retail and hospitality industry. But the health and well-being of our citizens must be the priority for all of us.One of the first associated casualties of the cancelled parade is Downpatrick and County Down Railwayrsquos planned park-and-ride service from Inch Abby to the town centre.Railway chairman Robert Gardiner said he estimated the not-for profit organisation would lose between pound,-pound, in income as a result.ldquoIf therersquos no carnival, therersquos no need for the park and ride, confirmed Mr Gardiner. ldquoWe normally carry about - people into Downpatrick on the day and they nearly all go to the carnival.ldquoWhile we can take this loss of income on the chin at the moment, we would be worriedthis continues as Easter is a very good holiday for us and we enjoyed a very busy summer last year..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar hosts meeting on future of unionism
story: THE first in a series of meetings to discuss the future of unionism in Rowallane was held last week in Crossgar.Guests included Lagan Valley MP Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, Orange Order Grand Secretary the Rev Mervyn Gibson and victimsrsquo campaigner Sammy Heenan.Organised by Rowallane councillors Kathryn Owen and Billy Walker, Crossgar Orange Order members and Crossgar Young Defenders Flute Band, last weekrsquos meeting has been hailed a great success.Around  people attended the meeting at Crossgar Orange Hall with plans confirmed for another in Saintfield over the coming weeks.Organisers say that they believe that local unionism is in a ldquomuch stronger place following the meeting with organisers thanking all those who took part.Also attending last weekrsquos meeting was Mr John Hanna, chairman of the UUPrsquos Strangfordrsquos Association.Cllr Owen said people spoke ldquoopenly and honestly during the meeting, with concerns voiced by those who attended ldquolistened to and discussed.She admitted while there is work to do across Northern Ireland, she is confident that unionism in Rowallane has taken a step in the right direction.Cllr Walker mdash who described the meeting as ldquoextremely worthwhile mdash thanked everyone who supported the event and encouraged people to attend the next one in Rowallane when the date and venue have been confirmed.ldquoThe turnout was tremendous and there was a lot of rank discussion which is good. I want to commend all those who took part and it is hoped that further meetings will take place in the near future, he said.ldquoIt is important that the unionist voice is heard at a local level and that meetings such as the one held last week are held regularly..prettyPhoto

title: Down hang on for draw with fiery Wicklow
story: A HARD-FOUGHT draw against Wicklow at Teconnaught on Sunday keeps Down Ladies on course for a place in the Division  League final.With Kildare beating Roscommon, it means a win away to Laois on March , will secure a final berth, ahead of playing Kildare at home in the final league fixture.As usual this winter, the wind was strong and favoured Down in the first half, although the home side failed to make full use of it. Too often the ball was lost in transition from defence to attack, with passes going astray or overhit and carried out by the wind.Wicklow looked dangerous in attack and were patient in possession. At half-time the teams were inseparable at six points each.Facing into the wind in the second half, Down noticeably upped their intensity and performance.Downrsquos defence was rock solid and while the link play, breaking forward was much better, there were a couple of goal opportunities that went abegging, on a day when a goal would have won the game.Down felt they definitely should have had a penalty when Natasha Ferris was pushed from behind, but unfortunately the referee saw an infringement in the opposite direction.With neither team able to pull clear, the game ended in a draw.Down scorers: Natasha Ferris , Jessica Foy , Sarah Dougherty , Eimear Fitzpatrick , Aoe Keown , Kate McKay .Down Ladies -Wicklow Ladies -NFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: Dr Campbell exposes Saint Patrick myths in new Netflix docu drama
story: THE director of the St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick will be appearing in a new featuredocu-drama debunking myths surrounding Irelandrsquos patron saint.Dr Tim Campbell, is one of a number of experts helping to peel back centuries of legend to tell the true story of St Patrick in I Am Patrick, which debuts on Netflix tomorrow.Programme makers from the American TV company Christian Broadcasting Network visited Dr Campbell last February to talk about the great Irish Saint.Dr Campbell says the film depicts St Patrickrsquos journey from slave to saint and exposes many of the hoods held by Americans.ldquoOne of the myths the documentary exposes is that St Patrick is unlikely to have picked a shamrock from a field while he preached to the natives about the Holy Trinity, he said.ldquoWe can deduce this because St Patrick left many writings and nowhere can be found the analogy of a shamrock.ldquoAlthough the Celtic people at the time worshipped nature and had a keen sense of worshipping in threes ndash St Patrick would have likely used their level of understanding and worked from there.The film is  minutes long and through historical re-enactments, expert interviews, and Patrickrsquos own writings, viewers experience the journey of the how Celtic people fell in love with the greatest of all Irish saints.As barbarians ravaged across Europe, a young teenager named Patrick, played by Robert McCormack, was enjoying a comfortable le as the son of a British political figure.Despite being a Christian, his faith didnrsquot mean anything to him until he was kidnapped by pirates at the age of  and enslaved in what was then the most uncivilised of lands mdash Ireland.For six years, Patrick was forced to work as a shepherd and was driven to the brink of starvation. It was then that he turned to his faith and before long managed to escape.He was ed to his family in Wales only to have a prophetic dream calling him to take Christianity back to the land he was so desperate to flee.Against the wishes of his family and the church, Patrick ed to Ireland as a missionary bishop and converted thousands to Christianity.Jarrod Anderson, writer and director of the movie filmed in Mayo, Galway and Clare said: ldquoMost people know about the green beer, banishing the snakes, and the parades but few actually know about the man behind the myths.ldquoWe filmed all across Ireland in some phenomenal locations and were able to create an epic docudrama with a stellar all Irish cast and crew..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C March 11%2C 1980
story: DRUMANESS mdash One regular in a pub will be sadly missed this weekend mdash unless someone responds to a plea from a heartbroken Drumaness family.Since the lsquoLassie type dog owned by the Rice family of the Park House Inn in the village went missing on Saturday night, things have not been the same among regulars at the bar.Family pet Rory was a favourite with customers at the bar and already they are missing him.This week Mr Hugh Rice made a plea for the person who took the collie dog toit.ldquoI last noticed Rory around .pm but shortly after that he vanished. I believe that someone tempted him into a car and drove off, Mr Rice explained.ldquoRory is three years old and his parents were both champions. We have had him since he was a pup and he became popular with customers and people around here.But the customers are not the only ones who are missing Lassie. Hughrsquos four children, Patrina , Hugh , Lisaand Roger , have been left heartbroken and all this week they have been out searching for him.Mr Rice has offered a reward and anyone who might know anything about Roryrsquos whereabouts should contact him at the Park House.RAHOLP mdash Champagne flowed at Cheltenham on Tuesday when local horses took on the might of England and won.Slaney Idol, owned by Mrs Mary Hynes, of Slaney Inn, Raholp, took the pound, prize in the Waterford Crystal Supreme novices hurdle, while Going Straight, owned by Mr Noel McGrady of Downpatrick finished fourth.The third local horse appearing at Cheltenham was Kickwyn, owned by Ballynahinch stables, S J Martin, but although it finished the Kim Muir Memorial Challenge Cup handicap chase it didnrsquot get among the prizes.But it was Slaney Idol, ridden by Tommy Carmody, that took the honours. Bred by Brian Hayes and trained by Liam Browne, it gradually moved through the field to the front runners with several fences to jump.It moved clear with one hurdle left and stayed in front of Daring Run to take the big prize.Going Straight, trained by Jeremy Maxwell at Ballee, was in a good position under near the end, but jockey Joe Byrne had to be content with fourth position.DOWNPATRICK mdash Five former students of Down High School, Downpatrick, are to be presented with the Duke of Edinburgh Gold Award.They are Stephen Calvert, Jonathan Gford, Gary McKee, James Milligan and Michael Wheeler, all from the Downpatrick area. The presentation will take place at Buckingham Palace, on March  and Prince Philip will attend.The group of Downpatrick lads joined in at least three of the same pursuits in their selection of four out of five sections in the scheme. Their activities included attending the local fire station on  dferent occasions for one night in the week. At the end of this period they were given a written examination.Then there was an expedition to the Mournes. Before this undertaking they were taught first-aid, the use of maps and compass and camp craft, including cookery.Furthermore they had to spend three nights under canvas, plan a  mile hike and when completed write an account of their experience.NEWCASTLE mdash The girls of St Maryrsquos school in Newcastle were feeling on top of the world this week mdash and itrsquos hardly surprising.The made quite an impact at the Portadown Festival of Speech and Verse, and theyrsquove got the medals to prove it.The most outstanding success was Catherine McInerney, who collected five medals and a certicate but seven of her schoolmates also featured in the awards.Geraldine Doran, Donna Corrigan, Orla Campbell, Tara Devlin, Orla Fitzsimons, Bronagh McInerney and Marve Boyle also impressed the Portadown judges.And just to round off a memorable week, two of the girls, Maeve Johnston also collected awards at the Belfast Festival.Meanwhile, not to be outdone, two teams entered by St Maryrsquos High School, Downpatrick, won the first and second awards at Portadown in the - years age section.And in the competition for the Ida Patterson Cup they were judged into second and third place.Another local school team for St Maryrsquos PS, Killyleagh, won the Kenmuir Cup in the - age group.KILLYLEAGH mdash A new Killyleagh firm bidding for Government sponsorship was given a massive boost at a major gardening exhibition in England this week.The firm, Killyleagh Box Company, displayed a selection of horticulture boxes made from extruded polypropylene, and substantial interest was shown in the product be people at the exhibition.The new firm is a subsidiary of the Inch-based C  C Trees Ltd and is based at factory space vacated by the tannery at Shrigley, beside Northern Ireland Plastics. And this week a co-director of the firm, Mr John Cushney, explained that they had plans to dramatically expand its operations.Mr Cushney explained that the new firm used the plastic material produced by Northern Ireland Plastics at Shrigley.The Box Company was operating on a small scale at present but they were seeking LEDU assistance and hoped to take on full-time workers shortly, said Mr Cushney.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Plessey, the electronics and communications giant which has a factory at Ballynahinch, announced signicant profits over the third quarter of the current financial year.A ,, advance was disclosed by the directors for this three month period, ending in December, giving a pre-tax total of pound,,.This result not only comfortably tops the earlier market estimates for Plesses, but more than wipes our the interim setback for group profitability.At the halfway stage the group results had been down by some pound,,.Thanks to the third quarter Plessey now shows nine monthsrsquo profits of pound,, mdash an improvement of pound,, on the same period in the previous financial year.ARDGLASS mdash The fishing industry along the Co Down coast is in danger of total collapse, a leading fisherman warned.The warning came from Mr Ian Morris, chairman of the Northern Ireland Fishing Organisation, and he stressed the port of Ardglass might even close.ldquoI donrsquot think it is exaggerating to say Kilkeel, Portavogie and even Ardglass could close. And who would care  Mr Morris asked.ldquoIt is only another , men or so unemployed and spread among the villages here. I think the Government could let us go to the wall.His warning came in a week of anxiety and protest for local fishermen. It was a comment which prompted Ardglass councillor, Mr Dermot Curran, to describe as being in a ldquoterrible situation.ldquoIt is a serious problem and is getting more serious each day. It is not just a question of conservation or mesh sizes, Mr Curran said.He emphasised the dependance of the town of Ardglass on the fishing industry and called for Agricultural Minister, Mr Giles Shaw, to look at the problems of the industry.CATHEDRAL mdash A former Ardglass rector, now rector at Newtownards, has been appointed Canon of Down Cathedral, as Prebendary of Dunsford. He is the Rev R J Chisolm, who succeeds the Rev J H R Good, of Carryduff, who becomes the new Precentor in Down Diocese.The Rev Chisolm has been rector of St Markrsquos, Newtownards, since , and is married with two sons. He will be installed by the Dean of Down, the Very Rev R W Kilpatrick, on Sunday.Mr Chisolm served his first curacy in St Donardrsquos, Belfast, before moving to Ardglass. He is a member of the South Eastern Education and Library Board and a founder member of the Northern Ireland Hospital Chaplainrsquos Association.Several other appointments have been made in the Chapter of Down Cathedral. Canon E S Barber, of Holywood, takes over as Chancellor in place of Canon A McKelvie, who is now retired and Canon H Leckey, of Bangor Abbey, takes over from Canon T H Frizelle, who is also retired..prettyPhoto

title: Gareth ready to take Top Hat to the Island Theatre stage
story: A LOCAL man will be putting on the style when he takes to the stage at the Island Theatre in Lisburn next week.Gareth McGreevy is following in the footsteps of movie legend Fred Astaire by taking the lead role in St Agnesrsquo Choral Societyrsquos production of Top Hat, which opens on Tuesday, March .A past pupil of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick, the  year-old, who is from Teconnaught but now lives in Carryduff, is no stranger to the stage.He has been performing since the age of five and has a string of credits to his name.He is probably best known locally for his involvement with the Downpatrick-based St Patrickrsquos Choral Society and Saul GACrsquos All-Ireland winning ballad group.He is the current chairman of St Agnesrsquo Choral Society and has worked tirelessly with the cast to help bring Top Hat to the stage.He said: ldquoItrsquos the cast that makes a show and this cast has put in a lot of hard work, blood and sweat to get this production ready for opening night.ldquoIrsquom really enjoying the great sense of unity and excitement among the members of the cast. Itrsquos the passion that drives and motivates us from opening night to when the curtain falls on the last nightrsquos performance.ldquoItrsquos makes for a lively stage set. I draw a lot of energy from how the audience reacts to the music and dancing.Gareth, who played the lead role in St Agnesrsquo Choral Societyrsquos award-winning production of nd Street in the Grand Opera House last year mdash it was named best show in  by the Association of Irish Musical Societies ndash says this latest production is his favourite show of all.ldquoTop Hat has enthralled generations of theatre goers and movie lovers with its music, eloquent tap dancing routines and costume designs, he remarked.ldquoFeaturing classic tunes such as Cheek to Cheek, Letrsquos Face the Music and Dance and the signature song, Top Hat, White Tie and Tails, the show is a real feast for the eyes.Gareth says he gets his musical talent from his grandmother, Esther McCormack, from Ballycran, and that singing acts like therapy for him.He said: ldquoIn the first half of this show alone we perform six songs. It is a very demanding role but it clearly agrees with me. I find singing and dancing are great for relieving stress.Laura Kerr, director of the show, said: ldquoWe are excited to be coming to the Island Hall for this six-show run of Top Hat. I know the audience will absolutely fall in love with the whole experience.ldquoThe mistaken identity storyline is hilarious, the songs are fantastic and the whole company is working tirelessly to give % on dance numbers that honestly belong on a West End stage.Top Hat will run at the Island Hall, Lisburn from next Tuesday until the following Saturday. All tickets are priced at pound and can be purchased through the Island Arts Centre Box Office, or by calling   .There will be the opportunity to make a donation to Belfast City Hospitalrsquos Renal Unit Fund at all performances..prettyPhoto

title: Kilclief GAC get £80k to help build new hub
story: KILCLIEF GAC has secured an pound, windfall for the creation of a new community hub.The money has been made available by the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership under the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsrsquo Leader programme.The funding mdash along with a signicant contribution from Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash will enable Kilclief GAC to transform an existing disused basement space to accommodate an indoor gym with adjoining changing and toilet facilities.There will also be space for a meeting  room, an IT studio and coffee dock which will complement the clubrsquos existing facilities.People of all ages and abilities in the wider Kilclief community will be able to avail of a wide range of cross-community activities within the new community hub.Council vice-chairman Terry Andrews welcomed the creation of a community hub in Kilclief.He said: ldquoThe enhanced facilities will provide the wider community with the opportunity to avail of new services which may otherwise be unavailable to them.Cllr Roisin Howell, who chairs the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Partnership, said it was ldquofantastic to see the benefits rural development funding can bring to rural communities.ldquoThe Partnership is delighted to approve Kilcliefrsquos community hub project, providing access to rural basic services for the people of the area, she added.Jerome Burns, a contract manager with the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, said the Leader programme, through which the Kilclief project will be funded, enables local people to determine the needs of their own area and decide how best to address these.ldquoThis is an excellent example of how the programme is enabling local decisions to be made for the benefit of the rural community in Kilclief, he said.He added: ldquoI have every confidence that Kilclief GAC, with its extensive number of dedicated volunteers and committee members, will enable this project to reach its full potential and be a resounding success for the future..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland Community Association new committee
story: THE new Loughinisland Community Association revealed its new committee as it met for its official launch last week.Chaired by Pat McGreevy, who is known for his work on the local Suicide Down  Zero group, the -strong committee will be working on achieving some quick fix improvements for all residents in the village ahead of gaining charitable status.Issues like improved street lighting and improving the footpath to the local shop are being considered ahead pursuing longer term goals such as a new community centre.Una Boyd, who is the secretary of the group, said that securing funding as a properly constituted charity was a key aim.ldquoThe creation of the community hall is on the long finger as we are still waiting on charity status before we can apply for grants, she said.ldquoCertainly the creation of the community centre was one of the main projects identied as need inthe Loughinisland Village Renewal Plan from .ldquoTherersquos a good firm plan of what the village needs but in terms of how we fund it and how we go about it, itrsquos all really early days yet.The plan was developed in consultation with local groups in Loughinisland by Newry, Mourne and Down Council as part of Northern Irelandrsquos Rural Development Programme.The committee is hoping to attract some more local people from key professions or with specic expertise to help strengthen the group..prettyPhoto

title: Major £56m investment for Castlewellan Forest Park
story: A MAJOR investment programme to make Castlewellan Forest Park one of the best in Ireland could top the pound.m mark.The figure was confirmed on Monday when local politicians agreed to appoint a dedicated design team to oversee major redevelopment work at the sprawling park which covers over , acres.Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash which is working to make the forest park one of Northern Irelandrsquos leading tourist attractions mdash has to date secured almost pound, in grant aid towards the cost of the ambitious project.The council has also committed just over poundm of its money to the project with a fresh application for pound.m to be submitted to the Heritage Lottery Fund in June, with an anxious wait until September to discover whether the bid has been successful.The funding secured to date has been provided by the Heritage Lottery Fundand Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs .Since the s, the sprawling forest park was the demesne of the Annesley family, who created a beautul landscape and a nationally and internationally important -hectare arboretum.The proposed development project aims to create a new vision for the historic Castlewellan demesne, delivering what is being described as a ldquoheritage-led destination to connect people with their built and natural heritage.Council officials and local politicians are keen to see the picturesque forest parkrsquos Arboretum, Annesley Garden and Grange Buildings redeveloped to help increase the number of visitors and provide the area with an economic boost.Officials say the focus is on improving amenities and the interpretation of the parkrsquos natural and built heritage.A recent economic appraisal recommended the development of what is being described as a welcome centre in the walled garden area designed to provide access via a lt to its upper floor, with the council keen to play a leading role, alongside the Forest Service, to help transform the parkrsquos fortunes and make it even more popular.At Mondayrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee, it was confirmed that the council currently holds a -year operating licence for the parkrsquos walking, bike and horse riding trails, in addition to play facilities.In addition, politicians were told that during a workshop in January to discuss the way forward, it was identied that formal links will be required with a number of organisations in relation to the future management of the parkrsquos Bothy Yard, glasshouses and propagation in particular.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is also hoping to secure a lease for the hugely popular park from the Forest Service and confirmed that once funding has been secured and the lease secured, it will pave the way for construction work to start.It has also been confirmed that local people will be asked for their views on the redevelopment of the forest park with public consultation on the way forward to be held sometime next month. Two previous consultation exercises have already been held.Councillors were told on Monday that the local authority may be asked to provide additional funding for the forest park development,the level of funding being sought from the Heritage Lottery Fund is not secured.They also agreed to investigate the potential of developing a partnership arrangement with Annes Grove in Cork which boasts an th century house and early th century garden, the latter of which includes a woodland garden with an interesting collection of rhododendrons, river garden, walled garden, wild-flower meadow and lily pond.Council officials believe there is merit for a joint marketing exercise involving Annes Grove and the Castlewellan park, alongside the propagation of trees and shrubs and student exchanges.Also on Monday, councillors granted permission for local authority officials to develop expressions of interest in vacant space at the forest park and hope that work to make one of the nest even better can get underway within months.Council officials say while they recognise the parkrsquos undoubted heritage signicance, parts of it require investment to preserve them and help promote an area which has ldquoexceptional tourism and recreational potential.It is envisaged that initial restoration work will focus on the -acre walled garden which is at the centre of the critically acclaimed arboretum, Bothy Yard and pathways which wind their way through the Rhododendron Wood..prettyPhoto

title: McCarron magic ends Strangford cup dream
story: THERE was to be no fairytale cup ending for Strangford when Ballynagross ruled the roost in Friday nightrsquos NFU Mutual Harry Clarke Cup semi-final at Bignian Park.Philip Campbellrsquos side displayed a ruthless streak when they brushed aside their giantkilling neighbours to book their place in the Easter Monday showdown for the third year in a row and they can now prepare for a massive derby clash with Celtic Bhoys.First half goals from twin terrors Daniel Taggart and Declan Dowie sent Ballynagross on their way and Eoin Rooney smashed in an unstoppable third midway through the second half to finally kill off a game Strangford side.In a competitive opening, Ballynagross used the width of the pitch to get at Strangford and with just two minutes gone Dowie had an effort cleared off the line after a cross from Rooney threatened to cause damage.Five minutes later Rooney had an effort hacked away to safety by an alert Conan Hynds as Ballynagross threatened to run riot.However, Donnie Ritchie started to get a few tackles in and his physicality in the engine room enabled Strangford to mount a few attacks of their own, using Conall Magee and Eoin King as willing outlets.Darting runs from Hynds and Ritchiersquos no-nonsense approach was just the ticket for Strangford and with  minutes gone Patrick Kerr had the ball in the back of the net only for it to be harshly ruled out for offside.Two minutes later at the opposite end, Cultra again saved from Rooney and followed that up with another good stop to deny Dowie.Strangford were becoming increasingly confident as teenage defenders Fionn McFaul and Thomas Fitzsimons settled into the job and with Ritchie and Hynds rattling a few cages, Niall Hyndsrsquo side started to look the part.However, they were left crestfallen in the th minute when Dowie broke free on the right and crossed for Taggart to flash a ing header into the net, somewhat against the run of play.It was a cruel blow for Strangford, but things were about to get worse, much worse.Referee Aide Sharvin who had a good game, had the whistle in his mouth to blow for half-time when the influential Connor McCarron sent Dowie clear and with the Strangford back four caught flat-footed, he lobbed the ball over Cultra with the last kick of the half to make it -.Strangford knew they had no choice but to throw caution to the wind after the break and that they did, but Aaron Beattie and Conor Marron gave absolutely nothing away at the back for Ballynagross and chances were hard to come by.Ballynagross were now able to hit Strangford on the break and with  minutes gone Cultra pulled off a stunning save to deny the overlapping Tom McNeill and then John Shields on the follow-up.With  minutes gone King blasted wildly over the top for Strangford before Ballynagross were denied what looked a stonewall penalty when Cultra emptied Rooney as he darted into the penalty box, but the referee waved play on.Ballynagross were not to be denied their third goal and with  minutes gone Shields played a delightful ball into the path of Rooney and from the right hand side of the box he unleashed a vicious volley that had goal written all over it from the moment it left his boot.Strangford still refused to throw in the towel and apart from a double save from close in by Cathail Arnold, they never really threatened, despite seeing their fair share of possession.Ballynagross could have won by a bigger margin, but Cultra stood big and tall and kept the final tally down with several more good saves.Ballynagross: Cathail Arnold, Tom McNeill, Deaglan Craig, Connor Marron, Aaron Beattie, Conor McCarron, Cormac Byrne, John Shields, Daniel Taggart, Eoin Rooney, Declan Dowie. Subs: Karl Johnston, Ryan McKinney, Ciaran Evans, Philip Doran, Gary Carberry.Strangford: Sean Cultra, Callum Smyth, Fionn McFall, Thomas Fitzsimons, Louis McMullan, Luke Reilly, Donnan Ritchie, Conan Hynds, Patrick Kerr, Eoin King, Conall Magee. Subs: Dale Curran, Hugo Panizo, Shea Savage, Niall Hynds, Russell Swail.Ballynagross Strangford HARRY CLARKE CUP SEMI-FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Profitable day for punters at Tyrella point to point meet
story: THE East Down Huntrsquos second point-to-point meeting of the season took place at David Corbettrsquos Estate at Tyrella on Saturday when, despite the recent wet weather, conditions were good.The meeting proved to be a good one for local owners, trainers and riders as they won four of the six races.One of the most exciting races of the day, despite only four going to post, was the Adjacent Hunt race, sponsored by William McDowell, of Seaforde, in memory of his father, Tom and Stephen Magee in memory of his father, Joe, who used to make a habit of winning the race.Notable that the previous evening at Dundalk, Stephen just failed to record his first success as a trainer when his Above Us Only Sky was just beaten by a head at  .In the hunt race, Ballynoe jockey Ross McLeigh, as he did when winning on the Liam Gibney-owned grey, Dento Des Obeaux, at the recent North Down meeting, set out to make the running, but with three fences to take was chased by another North Down winner in Double Smart, Declan Laveryrsquos only ride of the day.The leader, who was jumping well, held the advantage until the closing stages when Lavery drove his mount home for victory with Dento Des Obeaux followed home by Aaron Strongersquos Kraken Tale and Sam Hannarsquos Is This It.The winner is owned by Ardsrsquo couple Stephen and Yvonne Pearson, and is trained in Downpatrick by Paddy Turley, who was winning the race for the second year in succession.Six of the eight entries took part in the Robert McCoubrey Memorial winner of three race and here, Well Bill, runner-up to Like A Demon at the January meeting at the venue, reversed the placings with Evalabrune Drsquoor and Lee Byrne back in third.Owned by Armaghrsquos Clare Watson, the winner is trained by her son Marshal, who was at Gowran Park with one of his stable runners.This horse is one of only two pointers in the stable, both now having won in recent weeks. For winning rider, Daire McConville, from Portadown, it was an eighth winner between the flags.Twelve went to post in the Bluegrass and Dengie - mares maiden race and here we had a smooth winner in Ballela in the colours of Banbridge owner, Liam Cosgrove, who bought the horse back in August .Trained at Katesbridge by his brother, Gerry, the winner was ridden by Mark OrsquoHare in what was his only ride of the day.Going by Gerry, the winner, who likes any going, will now be sold.Interesting that Liam, who bred Apinchofluck, now owned and trained by Gerry Quinn, the former jockey, fell early in the race.Second place went to Mullaghmore Wave, trained by Alan Fleming, no longer the private trainer to Barry Connell, with Res Judicata third.Eleven went to post in the Irish National Hung chase committee six year-old and upwards maiden race for novice riders and here, Tardreee, in the colours of Templepatrick owner, Wilson Dennison, was sent into a long, clear lead and was always well clear as he came home by  s from Gigiplan Two Seven, ridden by Cathal McCormick, on his second local ride of the day.Red Lion, owned and trained by Co Antrimrsquos Richard Irwin was third. The winner is trained at the ownerrsquos estate by Colin McKeever and was ridden by Ballymenarsquos Paddy McGuigan for his second success. To me, he is a rider that deserves to get more rides than he does at at present.Largest field of the day was the  runner Albert Bartlett maiden race and as a result of a  start, all riders received a two-day ban.Victory went to Oscar Elite, trained in Wexford by Cormac Doyle and ridden by his stable jockey, James Hendrick, the combination winning from the Warren Ewing-owned and trained Here We Have it, ridden by Jordan Gainford, now riding the majority of his winners.There was a dead heat for third between Tommyrsquos Oscar and Pasvolsky, Chumlee and Dan Nevin were unlucky to be carried out by a posse horse when still in the lead.Six of the  entries went to post in the Dennison Commercials four year-olds auction race and only three finished, victory going to Greenrock Abbey, owned and trained by Wexfordrsquos Denis Murphy.Monkstreet was second ahead of Bolamore Bridge. No less than  horses took part in schooling after the last race.Among the best turned out in all races, courtesy of Glencairn Stables, were locals Robyn McCluskey, from Dromara and Sam Dickson, both involved with Colin McBratney yard at Raffrey. Acting stewards were Max and Margaret Ervine, James Armstrong and David Aiken..prettyPhoto

title: Unveiling of plaque commemorating Ballymote Centre founding member
story: A PLAQUE has been unveiled at the Ballymote Centre in Downpatrick to honour the memory of a local man who played a key role in its success.Architect Ciaran Taggart was one of the Killough Road shopping and community centrersquos founding members.The plaque unveiled during a recent ceremony attended by his we, Mary, and family members.The wall plaque was formally unveiled by current Ballymote Centre chairman Pat Branf, who paid tribute to Mr Taggart, highlighting the key role he played alongside a number of others  years ago to open the facility.Mr Taggart mdash who lived at the Killough Road mdash was an active Ballymote board chairman until his death in June last year.Paying tribute to the founder member, Mr Branf said Mr Taggart gave of his time and helped create hundreds of jobs.ldquoCiaran identied the need for a community centre in what were very troubled times in the area and when poverty and social unrest were re, he continued.ldquoFrom the early s, Mr Ciaranrsquos talents and energy were vital to this area. With other visionary people, he lobbied the government and secured almost poundm, also helping design the building and helped oversee its construction.Mr Taggart also volunteered with a number of other groups, making a signicant contribution to the health, social and cultural le of Downpatrick.During the recent unveiling ceremony, Mr Branf thanked Mrs Taggart and her family members for attending the ceremony and ldquofor everything Ciaran had accomplished.Mr Branf recalled that in , Mr Taggart helped raise over poundm to extend the current Ballymote Centre and construct the nearby health and well-being centre.ldquoThese community facilities now stand as testaments to the le of Ciaran Taggart, he continued, revealing that there are currently over  people in permanent jobs at this part of the town.Mr Branf added: ldquoThe whole community is indebted to Ciaran Taggart.On behalf of the Taggart family, Ciaranrsquos son, Diarmuid, thanked the Ballymote Centre board for its ldquothoughtfulness and spoke of his fatherrsquos ldquointense desire to be involved in the centre right up to the end and to be kept informed of the day-to-day business of the building.A number of people recalled their fond memories of Mr Taggart and their sadness at his passing last year.They said the buildings that he helped deliver for people in Downpatrick and wider Lecale area are a ldquofitting tribute to a great and modest man..prettyPhoto

title: coronavirus masses suspended
story: The Bishop of Clogher Larry Duffy has suspended all public Masses in the Diocese of Clogher amid the coronavirus pandemic.In a statement, Bishop Duffy said: "Having consulted with priests and lay people across the diocese, and mindful of public health and our capability or otherwise to maintain a congregation below , I am suspending all public Masses in the Diocese of Clogher with immediate effect."The Bishop claried that the Diocese of Clogher will follow health regulations in line with the Republic of Ireland for parishes on either side of the Border: "These regulations are motivated by a sense of care for the common good and, especially, for the most vulnerable. It is important that we minimize the movement of peopleand protect them from the virus and its effects.""At the same time, we must reach out as generously as we can to provide the best level possible of pastoral care," Bishop Duffy added.The current guidelines from the Bishop of Clogher state:- All are dispensed from the obligation to physically attend Sunday Mass and Mass on Holy Days of Obligation until further notice.- All are encouraged to participate in Sunday Mass and Mass on weekdays via radio, television or webcams that are in operation in many of our churches. A list of these, together with times of Masses and links to them will be available soon on the Diocesan Website ndashwww.clogherdiocese.ie.Other forms of audio-visual social media may also be used to enable people participate in the Mass.- Masses for weddings and funerals may continue, provided that the Government regulations are adhered to.- All Mass intentions for a given day or days can be incorporated into a Mass that is celebrated live on webcam or radio, or via any other audio-visual form of social media.- Priests are encouraged to celebrate Mass privately and to remember the needs of all their parishioners at this time, especially all those who are vulnerable and who may be infected by the Coronavirus.- All Confirmations are postponed until further notice. Be assured, however, that new arrangements will be made as soon as it is safe to do so.- First Confessions and First Holy Communions should also be suspended until further notice.- All non-essential pastoral gatherings and meetings are cancelled.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres.
